{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}} {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} [[File:NFL Experience at Super Bowl XLVII in New Orleans.jpg|thumb|The NFL Experience at [[New Orleans Morial Convention Center]] for [[Super Bowl XLVII]]]]
The '''Super Bowl Experience''' (formerly the '''NFL Experience''') is an annual event which has been held since 1992 at a venue in the host city of the [[Super Bowl]]. The event is described as an interactive "[[theme park]]",<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/la-gets-nfl-experience-39471/|title=L.A. Gets The NFL Experience |author= |date=January 25, 1993 |website= |publisher=[[Advertising Age]]|access-date=November 1, 2017 |quote= a ‘theme park’ event held outside game gates called the NFL Experience, which for the second year will bring sponsorship opportunities for national NFL advertisers and their local partners}}</ref> featuring various fan-oriented attractions, including [[American football|football]]-related activities and [[autograph]] sessions with current and former players.<ref name=":0" /> Proceeds from the sale of Super Bowl Experience tickets go to fund the NFL's [[NFL Youth Education Town|Youth Education Town]] (YET) initiative, which constructs facilities (typically in low-income neighborhoods of Super Bowl host cities) offering [[extracurricular activity|afterschool]] programs for youth.<ref name="fan" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sportsday.dallasnews.com/other-sports/superbowllocal/2011/02/03/jerry-jones-nfl-give-1-million-each-for-arlington_s-new-youth-education-town|title=Jerry Jones, NFL give $1 million each for Arlington's new Youth Education Town|date=2011-02-03|website=SportsDay|language=en|access-date=2019-01-28}}</ref>
In November 2017, the NFL opened an NFL Experience attraction at [[New York City]]'s [[20 Times Square]], in collaboration with [[Cirque du Soleil]], which featured a similar array of interactive experiences and memorabilia. Consequently, the NFL began to refer to the travelling event as the ''Super Bowl Experience'' beginning in 2018 for [[Super Bowl LII]] in [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]]. The Times Square experience was later closed.
==History== The first NFL Experience was held at the [[Minneapolis Convention Center]] in January 1992 prior to [[Super Bowl XXVI]]. The NFL's interactive theme park was followed by [[Major League Baseball]]'s first "FanFest" in [[San Diego, California]] six months later.
In 2013 the NFL Experience was hosted at the [[New Orleans Morial Convention Center]].<ref name="fan">{{cite web |url= https://www.fanhospitality.com/nfl-experience |title= NFL Experience |author= |date=|website= fanhospitality.com|publisher=|access-date=November 1, 2017 |quote= s}}</ref>
The NFL Experience was not held for [[Super Bowl XLVIII]]. Instead, the NFL organized an outdoor festival, Super Bowl Boulevard, along [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and [[Times Square]], which featured a similar array of fan-oriented events and attractions (such as an artificial toboggan hill).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/super/2014/01/23/super-bowl-xlviii-seattle-seahawks-denver-broncos-new-jersey-new-york/4806375/|title=New Jersey takes backseat in Super Bowl XLVIII billing|work=USA Today|access-date=November 30, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/01/super_bowl_2014_super_bowl_boulevard.html|title=Super Bowl 2014 fan guide: NFL 'Boulevard' on Broadway|work=NJ.com|access-date=November 30, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2013/2/12/3980680/2014-super-bowl-new-york-nfl-experience-nixed |title= 2014 Super Bowl will not have NFL Experience in New York|author= Jeff Briggs|date=February 13, 2013|website= |publisher=[[ SB Nation]]|access-date=November 1, 2017 |quote= }}</ref>
The 2015 NFL Experience was hosted at the [[Phoenix Convention Center]].<ref name="fan" />
The 2016 NFL Experience was hosted at the [[Moscone Center]] in San Francisco.<ref name=nbcbayarea>{{cite web|last=Roberts|first=Chris|title=Super Bowl 50 Gets Financial Boost from Big Tech|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/sports/Super-Bowl-50-Gets-Boost-From-Bay-Area-Tech-Companies--262055291.html|work=NBC Bay Area|publisher=NBCUniversal Media|date=October 15, 2014|accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref>
The 2017 NFL Experience was hosted at [[George R. Brown Convention Center]] in Houston. The Houston Super Bowl Host Committee also hosted its own outdoor festival, ''Super Bowl Live'', in the adjacent [[Discovery Green]] park, which featured entertainment events.<ref name="hpress-sblive">{{cite web|title=Super Bowl LIVE Kicks Off at Discovery Green|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/arts/super-bowl-live-kicks-off-at-discovery-green-9128633|website=Houston Press|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref><ref name="David Barron of the Houston Chronicle">{{cite web|last1=Barron|first1=David|title=Super Bowl LI "Opening Night" at Minute Maid on Jan. 30|url=http://www.chron.com/sports/texans/article/Super-Bowl-LI-Opening-Night-at-Minute-Maid-on-10620658.php|website=Houston Chronicle.com|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=February 13, 2017}}</ref>
For [[Super Bowl LII]], the event was renamed the '''Super Bowl Experience''', and was held at the [[Minneapolis Convention Center]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/twin-cities-setting-stage-for-super-bowl-lii-in-grand-fashion/443096043/|title=Twin Cities setting stage for Super Bowl LII in grand fashion|work=Star Tribune|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.twincities.com/2017/12/04/tickets-for-super-bowl-experience-theme-park-go-on-sale-tuesday/|title=Tickets for Super Bowl Experience ‘theme park’ go on sale Tuesday|date=December 5, 2017|work=TwinCities.com|access-date=December 5, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> The [[Super Bowl LIII]] edition was held at the [[Georgia World Congress Center]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ajc.com/sports/road-super-bowl-liii-nfl-likes-atlanta-layout-for-event/r5KXTk4jz56BJ5WuZPWtsO/|title=Road to Super Bowl LIII: Atlanta’s downtown cluster a perfect fit for NFL|work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|access-date=November 26, 2018}}</ref>
== NFL Experience Times Square == On November 30, 2017, the NFL opened an attraction known as '''NFL Experience Times Square''', within four ground-level floors of [[20 Times Square]] in New York City. The 40,000 square-foot attraction was a collaboration with [[Cirque du Soleil|Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group]], and featured various interactive activities and multimedia experiences, including a [[4D film]], a simulated locker room and practice area, displays of memorabilia, and a bar and restaurant that would feature a rotation of menu selections from NFL stadiums.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.travelandleisure.com/hotels-resorts/hotel-openings/marriot-edition-hotel-times-square-ian-schrager|title=This New Times Square Hotel Will Be Wrapped in New York City's Biggest Billboard|work=Travel & Leisure|access-date=November 30, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-29/the-future-of-cirque-du-soleil-isn-t-the-circus|title=The Future of Cirque du Soleil Isn’t the Circus|date=November 29, 2017|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|access-date=November 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/legit/news/nfl-times-square-cirque-du-soleil-1201802172/|title=Cirque du Soleil, NFL Team Up For Massive Times Square Attraction|last=Cox|first=Gordon|date=June 23, 2016|work=Variety|access-date=November 30, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2017/11/30/16716970/nfl-experience-times-square-football-theme-park-fans|title=The NFL opened up a football theme park in the middle of Times Square|work=SBNation.com|access-date=November 30, 2017}}</ref> In February 2018, it was announced that [[NFL Network]]'s ''[[Good Morning Football]]'' would move to a studio at the attraction in April, after having previously used a [[CBS]] studio in New York City.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/nfl/good-morning-football-moving-from-cbs-to-nfl-experience-times-square.html|title=Good Morning Football moving to new NFL Experience in Times Square|date=February 13, 2018|work=Awful Announcing|access-date=February 13, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
In September 2018, it was announced that the attraction would close, citing underperforming attendance numbers (which analysts pegged to poor promotion by the NFL, and high ticket prices). It was to remain open through at least the end of 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/325529/nfl-experience-sacked-during-first-year-opening-dr.html|title=NFL Experience Sacked During First-Year Opening Drive|work=MediaPost|language=en|access-date=November 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2018/11/26/Facilities/NFL-Experience.aspx|title=NFL Experience Still Open In Times Square Through End Of Year|website=Sports Business Daily|language=en|access-date=November 26, 2018}}{{subscription required}}</ref> ''Good Morning Football'' moved to [[SportsNet New York]]'s facilities at [[4 World Trade Center]] in November 2018.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dachman |first1=Jason |title=NFL Media Ramps Up for Exclusive London Broadcast; Good Morning Football Preps for Move to SNY |url=https://www.sportsvideo.org/2018/10/26/nfl-media-ramps-up-for-exclusive-london-broadcast-good-morning-football-preps-for-move-to-sny/ |website=Sports Video Group |accessdate=November 5, 2018 |date=October 26, 2018}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=September 2013}} The [[National Football League]] is the largest live spectator sporting league in the world (excluding auto racing) in terms of average attendance. {{see also|Intelligence quotient}} {{further information|Personnel selection}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Psychology sidebar}}
The '''Wonderlic Contemporary Cognitive Ability Test''' (formerly '''Wonderlic Personnel Test''') is a popular group intelligence test used to assess the learning and problem-solving [[aptitude]] of prospective employees for a range of occupations. The Wonderlic is available in 12 different languages and is often used for college, entry level jobs, and team-making evaluation. It consists of 50 multiple choice questions to be answered in 12 minutes.<ref name=Aiken1998>{{cite book|last=Aiken|first=L. R.|title=Tests and Examinations: Measuring abilities and performance|year=1998|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=New York|isbn=978-0-4711-9263-3|page=293|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_PxGAAAAMAAJ&q=tests+and+examinations&dq=tests+and+examinations}}</ref><ref name= Weaver1956>{{cite journal|last=Weaver|first=H. B.|author2=Boneau, C. A. |title=Equivalence of Forms of the Wonderlic Personnel Test: A Study of Reliability and Interchangeability|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|year=1956|volume=40|issue=2|pages=127–129|doi=10.1037/h0047065}}</ref><ref name=Pollick2003>{{cite web|last=Pollick|first=Michael|title=What is the Wonderlic Personnel Test|url=http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-the-wonderlic-personnel-test.htm|publisher=www.wisegeek.com|accessdate=March 29, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Wonderlic1939>{{cite journal|last=Wonderlic|first=E. F.|author2=Hovland, C. I. |title=The Personnel Test: a restandardized abridgment of the Otis S-A test for business and industrial use|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=December 1939|volume=23|issue=6|pages=685–702|doi=10.1037/h0056432}}</ref> The test was developed by Eldon F. Wonderlic, while he was a graduate student at [[Northwestern University]].<ref name="Pollick2003"/><ref name= wonderlic.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.wonderlic.com/about-us/history |title=History |publisher=wonderlic.com |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref><ref name= Schulte2004>{{cite journal|last=Schulte|first=Melanie|author2=Ree, M. J ., Carretta, T.R.|title=Emotional Intelligence: not much more than g and personality|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|year=2004|volume=37|issue=5|pages=1059–1068|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2003.11.014}}</ref> The score is calculated as the number of correct answers given in the allotted time. A score of 20 is intended to indicate average [[intelligence]] (corresponding to an [[intelligence quotient]] of 100).<ref name="Pollick2003"/> Wonderlic, Inc. claims a minimum score of 10 points suggests a person is [[literate]].<ref name="Merron">{{cite web|last=Merron|first= Jeff|year= 2007|title=Taking Your Wonderlics|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/closer/020228.html|website=espn.go.com}}</ref> A new version containing questions more appropriate to the 21st century was released in January 2007, called the Wonderlic Contemporary Cognitive Ability Test (formerly known as the Wonderlic Personnel Test – Revised). The test is available both online and in printed form, whereas the original test was only available on paper. The Wonderlic test was based on the Otis Self-Administering Test of Mental Ability.<ref name="Aiken1998"/><ref name="Wonderlic1939"/><ref name=Kazmier1959>{{cite journal|last=Kazmier|first=Leonard J.|author2=Browne, C .J. |title=Comparability of Wonderlic Test Forms in Industrial Testing|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|year=1959|volume=43|issue=2|pages=129–132|doi=10.1037/h0045688}}</ref>
==History== Created in 1936 by E. F. Wonderlic, the Wonderlic Personnel Test was the first short-form cognitive abilities test.<ref name="Pollick2003"/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|year=2012|title= History|url= http://www.wonderlic.com/about-us/history|website=wonderlic.com}}</ref> It was developed to measure [[g factor (psychometrics)|general cognitive ability]] in the areas of math, vocabulary, and reasoning.<ref name="Pollick2003"/><ref name="ReferenceA" /> Wonderlic created and distributed it as a graduate student in the psychology department at [[Northwestern University]] from his home.<ref name="Merron"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Regarding the time allotted to take the test, Eldon F. Wonderlic, in an article released in 1939, stated the following: "The length of the test was made such that only about two to five per cent of average groups complete the test in the twelve-minute time limit."<ref name="Wonderlic1939"/>
Originally designed to aid in employee selection, the Wonderlic Personnel Test has also been used by both the [[United States Armed Forces]] and the [[National Football League]] for selection purposes. During [[World War II]], the [[United States Department of the Navy|Navy]] began using the Wonderlic Personnel Test to select candidates for [[aviator|pilot]] [[training]] and [[air navigation|navigation]]. In the 1970s [[Tom Landry]], coach of the [[Dallas Cowboys]], was the first to use the Wonderlic Personnel Test to predict player performance.<ref name="Pollick2003"/> It is still used in the annual [[NFL Combine]] as a form of pre-draft assessment.<ref name="Pollick2003"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> In short, it attempts to screen candidates for certain jobs within the shortest possible time. It may be termed as a quick IQ test.<ref name="tests.com">{{cite web|title=Personality and Aptitude Career Tests. (2004). "Wonderlic personnel test: A short and quick iq test|accessdate=November 20, 2012 |url=http://www.personality-and-aptitude-career-tests.com/wonderlic-personnel-test.html|website=personality-and-aptitude-career-tests.com}}</ref>
The Wonderlic test is continually being updated with repeated evaluations of questions.<ref name="wonderlic.com"/><ref name="GARDNERLINDZEY19491101"/> Also, beginning in the 1970s, Wonderlic began to develop other forms of the Wonderlic Personnel some of which include: Wonderlic Perceptual Ability Tests, Wonderlic Scholastic Level Exam, or the Wonderlic Contemporary Cognitive Ability Test. There are currently 30 tests offered by Wonderlic, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|year=2012|title= Wonderlic Product Matrix|url=http://www.wonderlic.com/wonderlic-product-matrix}}</ref> ==Types== The tests are divided into four different sections: [[cognitive]], skill, personality, and [[behaviorism|behavioral]]. The scores are predictors of the possible conformity that a potential employee has within the field for which they are applying. Each test has a different number of questions and time requirement, and either can or cannot be administered via computer.
===Skill=== Created in the 1950s by Wonderlic's son, Charles F Wonderlic Sr., the skills test measures an individual's skill in areas such as math or English.<ref name=VLord89>[http://www.personality-and-aptitude-career-tests.com/wonderlic-scholastic-level-exam.html Wonderlic Scholastic Level Exam], access date March 21, 2012.</ref> There are three types of skill tests: Perceptual Ability Test, Wonderlic Basic Skills Test, and Wonderlic Office and Software Skills Tests. The Wonderlic Perceptual Ability Tests measures an individual's ability to answer numerical and alphabetical details with [[accuracy]]. The Wonderlic Basic Skills Test measures one's mathematical and verbal capabilities. Wonderlic Office and Software Skills Tests test a person's computer proficiency and use of basic software.<ref name="wonderlic">{{cite web|url=http://www.wonderlic.com/ |title=Ready. Test. Go |publisher=Wonderlic |accessdate=December 8, 2012}}</ref>
===Cognitive Ability (Wonderlic Personnel Test & Wonderlic SLE)=== Released in the 1990s, the Wonderlic Personnel Test measures an individual's capability of solving problems and learning. The Wonderlic Personnel test is divided into two different forms of test: the Wonderlic Personnel Test - Quicktest (30 questions in 8 minutes) and the Wonderlic Personnel Test (50 questions, 12 minutes). The Wonderlic Personnel Test-Quicktest differs from the Wonderlic Personnel Test in that it is not proctored giving employers a general idea of the potential applicant's cognitive ability. The Wonderlic Personnel Test is a much more comprehensive test.<ref name="wonderlic" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Wonderlic Test – Cognitive Ability Test|url=http://www.allpracticetest.org/wonderlic-exams/wonderlic-test-cognitive-ability-tests/|publisher=All Practice Test|accessdate=April 12, 2012}}</ref>
The Wonderlic SLE is the scholastic version of the Wonderlic Personnel Test and is commonly administered to nursing school and medical program applicants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://beatthewonderlic.com/blogs/news/what-is-the-wonderlic|title=What Is the Wonderlic?|work=Beat the Wonderlic|access-date=2017-03-13|language=en}}</ref>
===Behavioral liability=== Behavioral Liability is a test assessment for individuals to gauge that individual's potential in engaging in counterproductive or unethical behaviors within a community.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Martocchio|first=Joseph|author2=Judge, Timothy A |title=Relationship between conscientiousness and learning in employee training|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=October 1997|volume=82|issue=5|pages=764–773|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/apl/82/5/764/|accessdate=April 12, 2012|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.82.5.764|pmid=9337608}}</ref> Divided into two sections: the Wonderlic Behavioral Risk Profile and the Wonderlic Behavioral Risk Profile Plus.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.allpracticetest.org/wonderlic-exams/wonderlic-test-behavioral-reliability-tests/ Wonderlic Behavioral Test], access date March 21, 2012.</ref> Each test measures an individual's liability within the group, e.g., theft. The Wonderlic Behavioral Risk Profile test an individual's three [[trait theory|behavior traits]]: [[neuroticism]], [[agreeability]], and [[conscientiousness]]. The Wonderlic Behavioral Risk Profile Plus is similar to the Wonderlic Behavioral [[Risk]] Profile, however the Wonderlic Behavioral Risk Profile Plus contains additional questioning including background disclosures and productivity results.<ref name="wonderlic" />
===Personality=== The Wonderlic Personality tests measure personal characteristics that are widely accepted as being predictive of a candidate's expected [[job performance]]. Wonderlic claims that using the Wonderlic Personality Test to select individuals whose traits are aligned with the demands of the position, employers can improve employee productivity, employee satisfaction and customer service while reducing recruitment costs and employee turnover.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wonderlic|url=http://www.wonderlic.com/assessments/personality|accessdate=July 23, 2012}}</ref>
Added during the 1990s, the Wonderlic Personality Test contains two sections. The Wonderlic Five-Factor Personality Profile and the Wonderlic Seven-Factor Personality Profile. The Wonderlic Five-Factor Personality Profile tests individuals on five primary dimensions of the individual's personality: [[extraversion]], [[agreeableness]], [[conscientiousness]], [[neuroticism|emotional stability/neuroticism]], and [[openness to experience]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Description of Five Factor Model|url=http://www.personality-and-aptitude-career-tests.com/five-factor-model.html|accessdate=April 10, 2012}}</ref> These are essentially the same [[Construct (philosophy of science)|constructs]] as the [[Big Five personality traits]], also known as the Five Factor Model.
The Wonderlic Seven-Factor Personality Profile tests individuals on seven dimensions different from the Wonderlic Five-Factor Personality Profile: [[emotion|emotional intensity]], [[intuition (psychology)|intuition]], [[motivation|recognition motivation]], [[sensitivity (human)|sensitivity]], [[assertiveness]], [[Trust (social sciences)|trust]], and [[Impression management|good impression]]. The Wonderlic Seven-Factor Personality Profile test is oriented more for [[customer service]] employees.<ref name="wonderlic" />
==Sample questions== Similar to other [[standardized test]]s, the Wonderlic Cognitive Ability Test presents its questions in an open response format that becomes increasingly more difficult as one progresses through the test.<ref name="Wonderlic1939"/> The types of questions that have appeared in the oldest versions of the Wonderlic test include: [[analogy|analogies]], analysis of geometric figures, [[arithmetic]], direction following, disarranged sentences, [[judgment]], [[logic]], [[proverb|proverb matching]], similarities, and word definitions. However, the questions may take different angles depending upon the ‘intelligence’ of the question setters. <ref name="Wonderlic1939"/><ref name="Merron"/><ref name="tests.com"/> Practice questions will include: * If a piece of rope cost 20 cents per 2 feet, how many feet can you buy for 30 dollars? * Which of the numbers in this group represents the smallest amount? a) 0.3 b) 0.08 c) 1 d) 0.33 * A high-speed train travels 25 feet in 1/3 second. In 4 seconds, the train will have traveled __?__ feet.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://beatthewonderlic.com/blogs/free-wonderlic-practice-questions/free-wonderlic-personnel-test-50-questions-12-minutes|title=Free Wonderlic Practice Test - 50 Questions, 12 Minutes|work=Beat the Wonderlic|access-date=2017-03-13|language=en}}</ref> * A clock lost 2 minutes and 36 seconds in 78 days. How many seconds did it lose per day?<ref name="auto"/> Abbreviated, unofficial versions of the test are available online.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=wonderlic/090218 |title=The Wonderlic Exam – ESPN Page 2 |publisher=sports.espn.go.com |date=February 19, 2009 |accessdate=February 25, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wonderlictestsample.com|title=Take A Free Sample Wonderlic Test (50 or 25 Questions) {{!}} WTS|website=wonderlictestsample.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wonderlictestprep.com/wonderlic-practice-test|title=2018 Wonderlic Practice Test [Free] - 50 Sample Questions {{!}} Wonderlic Test Prep|work=WonderlicTestPrep|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}}</ref> While these tests are not nearly as complex as the original Wonderlic test, nor authorized by Wonderlic, they follow many of the same concepts.
A simplified and condensed version of the Wonderlic test appears in newer editions of the ''[[Madden NFL]]'' video game series.<ref name="Pollick2003"/> The ''Madden'' version of the test is taken in "Superstar Mode" portion of the game, to make the game experience more realistic, although, it is now optional.<ref>{{cite web|title=Madden NFL 11|url=http://nextdoorgamer.blogspot.com/2010/11/madden-nfl-11-superstar-mode.html#!/2010/11/madden-nfl-11-superstar-mode.html|accessdate=March 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=00.19|title=Madden NFL 10 (XBOX 360) Video Review – It's All In The Details|url=http://www.gamervision.com/users/00_19/articles/madden_nfl_10_xbox_360|publisher=www.gamervision.com|accessdate=March 29, 2012}}</ref> The questions usually consist of basic [[math]] and English questions. For example, "If [[Adrian Peterson]] [[Rush (gridiron football)|rushes]] for 125 yards in a game, how many yards will he have at the end of the season if he keeps up with this pace?". Players have four answers to choose from when taking this version of the test.<ref>EA Sports (2005). "NFL Superstar", ''Madden NFL 2006 (manual)'' (in English). Electronic Arts, page 11.</ref> ==Application to industrial-organizational psychology== {{See also|Industrial and organizational psychology}} The Wonderlic test, as a vocational and intelligence test, falls under the field of Industrial and Organizational Psychology. As a personnel test the Wonderlic is used to gauge an applicant's job potential, educational potential, and training potential.<ref name="Wonderlic1983"/> Six forms of this test are made available (A, B, C, D, E, and F) in which Wonderlic suggests that when two of these versions are to be used, the best combinations are A and B or D and F.<ref name="Kazmier">Kazmier, L.J. & Browne C.G.(1959). Comparability of Wonderlic test forms in industrial testing. Journal of Applied Psychology. 43(2):129–132.</ref> However, a study conducted by psychologists Kazmier and Browne (1959) shows that neither of these forms can be regarded as directly equivalent.<ref name="Kazmier" /> While there is no lack of tests that could be used in place of the Wonderlic, such as the IQ or the Mechanical Aptitude Test, it is a quick and simple vocational test for personnel recruitment and selection.<ref name=GARDNERLINDZEY19491101>{{cite news | url=http://web.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail?vid=4&hid=123&sid=e11e7c61-c644-4ba8-993b-82d253c55a5f%40sessionmgr12&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#db=psyh&AN=1949-05522-001 | title=Remarks on the use of the Wonderlic Personnel Test as a 'pre-test.'| work=Journal of Clinical Psychology| date=November 1, 1949 | accessdate=March 8, 2012 | author= Lindzey, Gardner}}</ref> The Wonderlic test has been peer reviewed by the [[American Psychological Association]] and has been deemed worthy of field applications to the industrial use of personnel testing.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dobrill|first=Carl|author2=Warner, Holly |title=Further studies of the Wonderlic Personnel Test as a brief measure of intelligence|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|date=February 1988|volume=56|pages=145–147|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/ccp/56/1/145/|issue=1|doi=10.1037/0022-006X.56.1.145|pmid=3346441}}</ref> Other sources can be found on the database APA PsycNET.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/index.cfm?fa=search.defaultSearchForm|title=PsycNET|website=psycnet.apa.org}}</ref> ==Reliability== {{See also|Reliability (statistics)}} In 1982, Carl Dodrill conducted a study in which 57 adults were administered the Wonderlic twice over a five-year period. In the ''[[Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology]]'', Dodrill reported that the test-retest reliability for the Wonderlic was .94.<ref name=Dodrill1983>{{cite journal|last=Dodrill|first=Carl|title=Long-Term Reliability of the Wonderlic Personnel Test|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|year=1983|volume=51|issue=2|pages=316–317|doi=10.1037/0022-006X.51.2.316}}</ref>
In 1956, Weaver and Boneau reported in the ''[[Journal of Applied Psychology]]'' that two of the five forms, A and B, that were published at the time were harder than the others which caused scores on those forms to be significantly lower than scores obtained on forms C–F.<ref name="Weaver1956"/> Concerning these observed differences, Weaver and Boneau state: "This accords with the history of the development of the test. Forms D, E, and F are made up of items selected from the Otis Higher, while A and B were developed later and include types of items not found in the Otis."<ref name="Weaver1956"/> Those findings, seemingly, invalidate the claim that those forms were equivalent or consistent.<ref name="Weaver1956"/> E. N. Hay made a similar observation as well. Hay found that form F was significantly easier than Form D.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hay|first=E. N.|title=Some research findings with the Wonderlic Personnel Test|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|year=1952|volume=36|issue=5|pages=344–345|doi=10.1037/h0061766}}</ref> Furthermore, Kazmier found Form B to be the most difficult of the five forms and, thus, recommended that it "not be regarded as directly equivalent to any of the forms."<ref name="Kazmier1959"/> Kazmier also found Forms D and F to be significantly different from each other and recommended that these forms be regarded as inequivalent.<ref name="Kazmier1959"/> In a study of the Wonderlic's test-retest reliability, conducted in 1992, Stuart McKelvie "concluded that conscious repetition of specific responses did not seriously inflate the estimate of test-retest reliability."<ref name= McKelvie1992>{{cite journal|last=McKelvie|first=Stuart J.|title=Does memory contaminate test-retest reiliability|journal=Journal of General Psychology|date=January 1992|volume=119|issue=1|pages=59–72|doi=10.1080/00221309.1992.9921158|pmid=1613489}}</ref> To put it simply, one's memory of some of the answers does not significantly affect one's score on the Wonderlic.<ref name="McKelvie1992"/>
More recently, according to a 1989 article in ''[[Psychological Reports]]'', the Wonderlic scored a r=.87 on the reliability scale compared along with the Pearson test score of r=.21.<ref name=Matthews2007>{{cite journal|last=Matthews|first=T|author2=Kerry S. Lassiter |title=WHAT DOES THE WONDERLIC PERSONNEL TEST MEASURE?|journal=Psychological Reports|year=2007|volume=100|pages=707–712|doi=10.2466/pr0.100.3.707-712|issue=3|pmid=17688083}}</ref> ==Validity== {{See also|Validity (statistics)}} In an article written in ''[[Psychological Reports]]'', T. Matthews and Kerry Lassiter report that the Wonderlic test "was most strongly associated with overall intellectual functioning," which is what it is purported to measure.<ref name="Matthews2007" /> However, Matthews and Lassiter did not find the Wonderlic to be a successful measure of [[fluid and crystallized intelligence]], and they stated that "the Wonderlic test scores did not clearly show convergent or divergent validity evidence across these two broad domains of cognitive ability."<ref name="Matthews2007" /> In academic testing, the Wonderlic test has shown high correlations with aptitude tests such as the General Aptitude Test Battery.<ref name="Matthews2007" /> ==Legal Issues== ===''Jordan v. New London''=== In May 1997, Robert Jordan filed a lawsuit against the city of [[New London, Connecticut]], alleging violation of the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the United States and Connecticut constitutions, in a case that was referred to by several media outlets as "Too Smart To Be A Cop".[https://www.cbsnews.com/news/too-smart-to-be-a-cop/][https://slate.com/business/2013/05/too-smart-to-be-a-cop.html], based on the City's application of scores generated by the Wonderlic test.
Jordan was born and raised in New London, and had previous experience in law enforcement, working as a part-time officer in near-by [[Groton Long Point]], and as a seasonal officer for the [[Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection]]. In the fall of 1996, Jordan requested an interview with Keith Harrigan, New London's Assistant City Manager in charge of personnel. Harrigan informed Jordan that he was ineligible because he scored too high on the written portion of the Wonderlic test intended to evaluate cognitive ability. New London had decided to consider only applicants who scored between 20 and 27 on the written examination. Jordan scored a 33 on the exam, the equivalent of having an IQ of 125.
Jordan filed suit in the [[United States District Court for the District of Connecticut]], where his case was dismissed by Judge Peter C. Dorsey, who noted: "The guarantee of equal protection under the Fifth Amendment is not a source of substantive rights or liberties, but rather a right to be free from invidious discrimination in statutory classifications and other governmental activity. It is well settled that where a statutory classification does not itself impinge on a right or liberty protected by the Constitution, the validity of the classification must be sustained unless the classification rests on grounds wholly irrelevant to the achievement of [any legitimate government] objective....[Jordan] may have been disqualified unwisely but he was not denied equal protection." [http://www.aele.org/apa/jordan-newlondon.html] The dismissal was upheld on appeal to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]].
==Central tendency of Wonderlic scores== {{See also|Central tendency}} Serving as a quantitative measure for employers, scores are collected by the employers and the applicant's score may be compared to a professional standard, as is the case with security guards or, simply, compared to the scores of other applicants who happen to be applying for the same or similar positions at that time.<ref name=Wonderlic1983>{{cite book|title=Wonderlic Personnel Test Manual|year=1983|publisher=E.F. Wonderlic & Associates, INC|location=Northfield, IL}}</ref> Each profession has its own, unique, average; therefore, different professions require different standards.<ref name="Wonderlic1939"/><ref name="Wonderlic1983"/>

title=Wonderlic reaches well beyond NFL | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/draft/2006-04-16-wonderlic-feature_x.htm | accessdate=November 12, 2013 | newspaper=[[USA Today]] | date=April 16, 2006 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112182806/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/draft/2006-04-16-wonderlic-feature_x.htm | archivedate=November 12, 2013 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Pat McInally]] – 50 (fifth-round pick in the [[1975 NFL Draft]]; only player known to have gotten a perfect score)<ref name="mcclellan20060615">{{cite web | last=McClellan | first=Bob | url=http://collegefootball.rivals.com/content.asp?CID=553028 | title=McInally continues to perfect the Wonderlic | publisher=[[Rivals.com]] | date=June 15, 2006 | accessdate=April 25, 2011 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024125307/http://collegefootball.rivals.com/content.asp?CID=553028 | archivedate=October 24, 2013 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Predictor of success in the NFL==== John P. Lopez of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' proposed a 26–27–60 rule to predict a quarterback's success in the NFL (at least a 26 on the Wonderlic, at least 27 college starts, and at least 60% [[completion (American football)|pass completion]]) and listed several examples of successes and failures based on the rule.<ref name="lopez20100708">{{Cite magazine |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2010/writers/john_lopez/07/08/qb.rule/index.html?xid=cnnbin&hpt=Sbin |title=The Rule of 26–27–60 helps predict NFL quarterback success or failure |last=Lopez |first=John P. |date=July 8, 2010 |magazine=Sports Illustrated |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018000523/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2010/writers/john_lopez/07/08/qb.rule/index.html?xid=cnnbin&hpt=Sbin |archive-date=2013-10-18}}</ref> A 2005 study by McDonald Mirabile found that there is no significant correlation between a quarterback's Wonderlic score and a quarterback's passer rating, and no significant correlation between a quarterback's Wonderlic score and a quarterback's salary.<ref name="mirabile2005">{{cite journal | url=http://www.thesportjournal.org/article/intelligence-and-football-testing-differentials-collegiate-quarterback-passing-performance-a | title=Intelligence and Football: Testing for Differentials in Collegiate Quarterback Passing Performance and NFL Compensation | publisher=United States Sports Academy | date=Spring 2005 | accessdate=April 25, 2011 | last = Mirabile | first = McDonald P. | journal=The Sport Journal | volume=8 | issue=2}}</ref> Similarly, a 2009 study by Brian D. Lyons, Brian J. Hoffman, and John W. Michel found that Wonderlic scores failed to positively and significantly predict future NFL performance, draft position, or the number of games started for any position.<ref name="lyons2009"/><ref name="ledbetter20100306">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ajc.com/sports/atlanta-falcons/nfls-success-using-wonderlic-352405.html |title=NFL's success using Wonderlic Test subject to interpretation |last=Ledbetter |first=D. Orlando |date=March 6, 2010 |work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution |access-date=May 14, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527074021/https://www.ajc.com/sports/atlanta-falcons/nfls-success-using-wonderlic-352405.html |archive-date=2010-05-27}}</ref> Lyons said that Wonderlic's "limited return on investment" for the NFL is contrary to [[general mental ability]] being a very strong predictor of job performance for most careers; "because it's so physically based, the results point to that [GMA] really doesn't matter".{{r|ledbetter20100306}} [[Donovan McNabb]], whose score{{r|oktc}} was the lowest of the five quarterbacks taken in the first round of the [[1999 NFL Draft]], had the longest and most successful career.<ref name="gladwell20081215">{{cite news | url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2008/12/15/081215fa_fact_gladwell?currentPage=all | title=Most Likely to Succeed | work=The New Yorker | date=December 15, 2008 | accessdate=January 12, 2013 | last=Gladwell | first = Malcolm}}</ref>
The Lyons study also found that the relationship between Wonderlic test scores and future NFL performance was negative for a few positions, indicating the higher a player scores on the Wonderlic test, the worse the player will perform in the NFL.<ref name="lyons2009">{{cite journal |title=Not Much More than g? An Examination of the Impact of Intelligence on NFL Performance |first1=Brian D. | last1 = Lyons |first2=Brian J. | last2 = Hoffman |first3=John W. | last3 = Michel |date=July 1, 2009 |journal=Human Performance |volume=22 |issue=3 |doi=10.1080/08959280902970401 |page=225}}</ref> According to [[Pat McInally]], who was selected by the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in the fifth round of the [[1975 NFL Draft]], [[George Young (American football executive)|George Young]] told him that his perfect score caused him to be selected later than he would have otherwise.<ref name="lopresti20110926">{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/columnist/lopresti/story/2011-09-26/ryan-fitzpatrick-bills-3-0-harvard/50559292/1 | title=Harvard's Ryan Fitzpatrick gets passing grades for 3–0 Bills | work=USA Today | date=September 26, 2011 | accessdate=October 3, 2011 | last=Lopresti | first = Mike}}</ref> NFL reporter Matt Verderame reported that [[New England Patriots]] offensive lineman [[Joe Thuney]] avoided answering Wonderlic questions so he would not score too high.<ref>{{cite web|title=Patriots player avoided Wonderlic questions so he wouldn't 'scare teams off' with his intelligence|language=en|author=Jordan Heck|date=30 July 2019|website=Sporting News|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nfl/patriots-player-avoided-wonderlic-questions-so-he-wouldnt-scare-teams-off-with-his-intelligence/ar-AAF4lUm?ocid=spartanntp}}</ref> McInally speculated that "coaches and front-office guys don't like extremes one way or the other, but particularly not on the high side. I think they think guys who are intelligent will challenge authority too much".<ref name="mcclellan20060615"/> Mike Florio of [[Profootballtalk.com]] agreed with McInally:<ref name="florio20110228">{{cite web | url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2011/02/28/greg-mcelroy-gets-a-48-on-the-wonderlic/ | title=Greg McElroy gets a 48 on the Wonderlic | publisher=NBC Sports | work=Profootballtalk.com | date=February 28, 2011 | accessdate=April 25, 2011 | last=Florio | first = Mike}}</ref>
{{quote|Scoring too high can be as much of a problem as scoring too low. Football coaches want to command the locker room. Being smarter than the individual players makes that easier. Having a guy in the locker room who may be smarter than every member of the coaching staff can be viewed as a problem – or at a minimum as a threat to the egos of the men who hope to be able when necessary to outsmart the players, especially when trying in some way to manipulate them.}}
[[Job performance]] in the NFL also includes deviance. A 2016 study found that the Wonderlic significantly predicted future arrests — referred to as criminal off-duty deviance — [[National Football League player conduct controversy|in NFL draftees]].<ref name="seifert20160412">{{Cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/201565 |title=Using data to predict arrest rates of NFL draft picks |last=Seifert |first=Kevin |date=2016-04-12 |website=ESPN.com |language=en |access-date=2019-02-10}}</ref>

The [[National Football League]] (NFL) and the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) are respectively the most popular professional and amateur [[American football|football]] organizations in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/ducks/index.ssf/2012/05/head_of_new_usfl_believes_it_c.html|title=New version of United States Football League aims to succeed where others have failed|last=Fentress|first=Andrew|date=May 18, 2012|work=[[OregonLive.com|Oregon Live]]|publisher=[[Advance Internet]]|accessdate=January 9, 2013}} The National Football League was founded in 1920{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/2005/1/1/nfl-founded-in-canton/|title=NFL founded in Canton|publisher=[[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]|accessdate=November 26, 2012}} and has since become the largest and most popular sport in the United States.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/sport/china/article/1090060/china-fast-catching-american-football-fever-10-teams-formed|title=China fast catching American football fever with 10 teams formed|last=Chin|first=Andrew|date=November 25, 2012|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|accessdate=November 26, 2012}} The NFL has the highest average attendance of any sporting league in the world, with an average attendance of 66,960 persons per game during the [[2011 NFL season]].{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/gametheory/2011/09/ranking-sports%E2%80%99-popularity|title=And the silver goes to ... |date=September 27, 2011|work=[[The Economist]]|accessdate=December 6, 2012}} While the NFL championship game, the [[Super Bowl]], is a large sporting event in club sports it does not compare in popularity to cricket and international football (soccer), which both have billions of spectators.{{cite news|title=Elite clubs on Uefa gravy train as Super Bowl knocked off perch|last=Harris|first=Nick|date=January 31, 2010|work=[[The Independent]]|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/elite-clubs-on-uefa-gravy-train-as-super-bowl-knocked-off-perch-1884429.html|accessdate=November 28, 2012}} It is played between the champions of the [[National Football Conference]] (NFC) and the [[American Football Conference]] (AFC), and its winner is awarded the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sectionfront/life/lets-learn-about-the-vince-lombardi-trophy-356977/|title=Let's Learn About: The Vince Lombardi Trophy|last=George|first=Shannon|date=September 10, 2009|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=January 9, 2013}} Collegiate football ranks third in overall popularity in the United States, behind baseball and pro football.{{cite web|url=http://www.harrisinteractive.com/NewsRoom/HarrisPolls/tabid/447/mid/1508/articleId/950/ctl/ReadCustom%20Default/Default.aspx|title=Football is America's Favorite Sport as Lead Over Baseball Continues to Grow|date=January 25, 2005|publisher=[[Harris Insights & Analytics|Harris Interactive]]|accessdate=November 26, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127211007/http://www.harrisinteractive.com/NewsRoom/HarrisPolls/tabid/447/mid/1508/articleId/950/ctl/ReadCustom%20Default/Default.aspx|archive-date=January 27, 2013|url-status=dead}} The NCAA, the largest collegiate organization, is divided into three Divisions: [[NCAA Division I|Division I]], [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] and [[NCAA Division III|Division III]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/NCAA/About+the+NCAA/index.html|title=About the NCAA|publisher=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA.org]]|accessdate=January 9, 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130118120358/http://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/NCAA/About%2Bthe%2BNCAA/index.html|archivedate=January 18, 2013}} Division I football is further divided into two subdivisions: the [[Football Bowl Subdivision]] (FBS) and the [[NCAA Division I#Football Championship Subdivision|Football Championship Subdivision]] (FCS).{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/ncaa/about+the+ncaa+old/who+we+are/differences+among+the+divisions/division+i/about+division+i|title=Differences Among the Three Divisions: Division I|publisher=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA.org]]|accessdate=January 9, 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104204838/http://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/ncaa/about%2Bthe%2Bncaa%2Bold/who%2Bwe%2Bare/differences%2Bamong%2Bthe%2Bdivisions/division%2Bi/about%2Bdivision%2Bi|archivedate=November 4, 2013}} The champions of [[NCAA Division I Football Championship|Division I-FCS]], [[NCAA Division II National Football Championship|Division II]] and [[NCAA Division III National Football Championship|Division III]] are determined through playoff systems, and the [[College football national championships in NCAA Division I FBS|Division I-FBS]] champion was determined through the Bowl Championship Series (BCS). Division I-FBS switched to a four-team playoff system in 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/NCAA/Championships/Postseason+Football/Overview|title=Postseason Football|publisher=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA.org]]|accessdate=January 9, 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522204127/http://www.ncaa.org/wps/wcm/connect/public/ncaa/championships/postseason%2Bfootball/overview|archivedate=May 22, 2012}} ==Major rule differences== Some of the major rule differences between NFL and [[College football#Official rules and notable rule distinctions|college football]] include: {| class="wikitable" |- !  ! [[American football rules#NFL|NFL]] ! [[American football rules#College and high school|College football]] |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Number of feet a receiver must have in bounds for a completed pass | Both | Only one |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Down by contact rule | Yes, a player is active until he is tackled or forced down by a member of the opposing team | No, a player is automatically ruled down when any part of his body other than the feet or hands touches the ground |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Penalty for defensive pass interference | Automatic first down at the spot of the foul | Automatic first down, with the lesser of 15 yards from the previous spot or the spot of the foul |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Clock temporarily stops after the offense completes a first down so the chain crew can reset the chains | No, the clock does not explicitly stop for a first down | Yes |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Defensive Holding | 5 yard penalty, Automatic first down | 10 yard penalty, repeat the down unless 1st down gained by penalty yardage |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Spot where an opposing team takes possession after a missed field goal | The greater of the spot of the kick or the opposing team's 20-yard line | The greater of the previous line of scrimmage or opposing team's 20-yard line |- ! style="text-align:left;" | [[Two-minute warning]] (an automatic time out when two minutes remain in each half) | Yes | No, it is not used |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Starting point of a one- or two-point [[Conversion (gridiron football)|conversion]] | Fifteen-yard line for one-point and two-yard line for two-point | Three-yard line for both |- ! style="text-align:left;" | Overtime | [[Sudden death (sport)|Sudden death]] using basically the same rules as in regulation, except if the team that receives the kickoff scores a field goal on its first possession, it then kicks off to the opposing team with an opportunity to score; if the score is tied again after that possession, true sudden death rules apply. During preseason and regular season games, only one overtime period is played and the game can simply end in a tie; during playoff games, multiple overtime periods may be held until one team scores. | Each team is given one possession from its opponent's twenty-five yard line with no game clock. The team leading after both possessions is declared the winner. If the teams remain tied, overtime periods continue; games cannot end in a tie. Teams that possesses the ball first in each period alternates. Starting with the third overtime, teams are only allowed to attempt two-point conversions after a touchdown. |- ! style="text-align:left;" | [[Instant replay]] | Scoring plays, turnovers, and plays during the final two minutes of each half and all overtime periods are subject to booth review. Coaches are issued two challenges (with the option for a third if the first two are successful) to request a review for all other plays | All plays are subject to booth reviews. Coaches only have one challenge per game. |- ! style="text-align:left;" | [[Hash marks#Usage in gridiron football|Hash marks]] | 18 feet 8 inches apart (the width of the goal posts) | 40 feet apart |} ==Overview== {{see also|List of NCAA Division I FBS football programs|List of NCAA Division I FCS football programs}} The NFL consists of [[2002 NFL season#Expansion and realignment|thirty-two clubs]] divided into two conferences of sixteen teams each. Each conference is divided into four divisions of four clubs each. The NFL season format consists of a four-week [[National Football League preseason|preseason]], a seventeen-week [[National Football League regular season|regular season]], and a twelve-team [[NFL Playoffs|single-elimination playoff]] culminating in the [[Super Bowl]], the league's championship game. College teams mostly play other similarly sized schools through the NCAA's divisional system. [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] generally consists of the major collegiate athletic powers with larger budgets, more elaborate facilities, and more athletic scholarships. [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] primarily consists of smaller public and private institutions that offer fewer scholarships than those in Division I. [[NCAA Division III|Division III]] institutions also field teams, but do not offer any scholarships. Football teams in Division I are further divided into the [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Bowl Subdivision]] (consisting of the largest programs) and the [[NCAA Football Championship Subdivision|Championship Subdivision]]. The Bowl Subdivision (FBS) previously did not have an organized tournament to determine its champion; instead, teams competed in post-season [[list of college bowl games|bowl games]]. Up through the 2013 season, the BCS National Championship game determined the national champion. The game featured the #1 and #2 teams in the BCS rankings, a mixture of computer and human polls ranking the top teams in the country. Beginning in the 2014 season, a 4-team playoff now determines the national champion. The four teams competing in the [[College Football Playoff]] are decided by a 13-member selection committee using a complex set of selection criteria and each committee member valuing certain selection criteria differently. These criteria include Strength of Schedule, Conference Championships, Win-Loss Record, On-field play, non-conference schedule and much more. The importance of traditional major bowl games will be preserved by using 2 of the 6 major bowls as the semi-finals of the playoff while the remaining 4 will incorporate traditional conference "tie-ins" to schedule teams in each bowl game.{{cite web|url=http://www.collegefootballplayoff.com/overview|title=Overview - College Football Playoff|publisher=|accessdate=6 March 2017}} The Championship Subdivision utilizes a college football playoff, the [[NCAA Division I Football Championship]]. As of 2014, 24 teams are selected for the playoff. Similar to the NCAA College Basketball Tournament, each conference champion received an automatic bid to the tournament. The remaining tournament berths are awarded as "at-large" selections by a selection committee.{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.com/interactive-bracket/football/fcs|title=2016 FCS Championship Bracket|publisher=|accessdate=6 March 2017}} ==Metros table== {| class="wikitable" !
