The '''London NFL franchise''' is a hypothetical [[National Football League]] (NFL) [[American football]] team based in London, England; formed as a new [[expansion team]], or by [[National Football League franchise moves and mergers|relocating]] one of the existing 32 NFL teams currently based in the United States. Should the league establish a team in London, it would become the first of the [[major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada]] to establish a franchise outside either of those two countries.
A London NFL franchise would be intended to grow the league's [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada#Revenues|revenues]] and provide further access to the British and [[Europe]]an markets. However, the [[Potential London NFL franchise#Mechanics|agreement of league owners]] is needed to undertake an expansion or relocation, and a London franchise would face [[Potential London NFL franchise#Issues|financial, legal and logistical challenges]]. Possible home stadiums for the London team include one or more of [[Wembley Stadium]], [[Twickenham Stadium]] or [[Tottenham Hotspur Stadium]].
The NFL is aiming to establish a London franchise by around 2025, and has the active support of the British government. Since 2007, the league has held multiple [[NFL regular season|regular season]] games in London each season as part of [[NFL International Series|NFL London Games]], allowing the league to test solutions to some of the challenges facing a hypothetical London franchise.
==Background== Although [[American football in the United Kingdom]] has historically been a niche sport, British interest in the NFL peaked in the 1980s, in which time London hosted some [[American Bowl|pre-season games]]; during the 1990s, the city hosted the [[London Monarchs]] in the league's developmental [[NFL Europe|Europe League]].<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014>{{cite web|url=http://mmqb.si.com/2014/10/02/nfl-team-in-london-international-series |title=Why London? And Can It Work? |date=October 2, 2014 |author=The MMQB}}</ref> However, as all NFL Europe franchises outside Germany and the Netherlands, the Monarchs were ultimately relocated due to lack of public interest. Popular interest waned with the growth of the [[Premier League]] in the 1990s, although it grew again from 2007 following the establishment of the International Series. It also led to steady increases in actual participation in amateur games.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
==Mechanics== An affirmative vote of three-quarters of the owners of the NFL's 32 clubs is required before a new team can be created (known as expansion) or before an existing team is allowed to move to a new market (known as relocation), i.e. 24 or more clubs would have to approve of the decision.<ref name=NFLAP5May2012>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d828e3933/printable/vikings-in-limbo-and-expansion-not-on-nfls-radar |title=Vikings in limbo and expansion not on NFL's radar |date=May 5, 2012 |agency=Associated Press (via NFL.com)}}</ref><ref name=Reuters5January2016>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nfl-relocation-idUSKBN0UJ0A520160105 |title=Three NFL teams apply to move to Los Angeles area |date=January 5, 2016 |agency=Reuters}}</ref>
According to ''The Guardian'', as of 2015 it was "well-known" that a London franchise was a goal of the NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]], although "he tends to avoid specifics on the process to make that happen".<ref name=TheGuardian4August2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/aug/04/how-close-are-we-to-a-london-jaguars-nfl-franchise |title=How close are we to a London Jaguars NFL franchise? |date=August 4, 2015 |author=The Guardian}}</ref> The NFL's Executive Vice President International [[Mark Waller (American football executive)|Mark Waller]] is more specific, expressing the goal as "to build a fanbase that would be able to support a franchise".<ref name=BusinessReporter2October2015>{{cite web|url=http://business-reporter.co.uk/2015/10/02/george-osborne-backs-drive-for-nfl-franchise-in-london/ |title=George Osborne backs drive for NFL franchise in London |date=October 2, 2015 |author=Business Reporter}}</ref> According to [[Atlanta Falcons]] owner [[Arthur Blank]] speaking in 2014, "The approach that the international committee and the commissioner have taken is, "Let's do London right, and then move from there to potentially somewhere else"."<ref name=NBC2June2014/>
===Expansion franchise=== In the opinion of former NFL executive [[Jim Bailey (American football)|Jim Bailey]], the NFL would probably prefer to create a London-based franchise through the expansion route, since that would offer them more control over the process.<ref name=ESPN25September2013>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9716479/nfl-team-london-raises-legal-issues |title=NFL in London raises legal issues |date=September 25, 2013 |author=ESPN}}</ref> According to CBS however, as of 2012 the club owners were generally satisfied with the league's 32 team model, and would prefer a relocation.<ref name=CBS28October2012>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/writer/jason-la-canfora/20724077/nfls-move-to-london-could-come-soon-jags-a-target |title=NFL's move to London could come soon; Jags a target |date=October 28, 2012 |author=CBS}}</ref> According to the Associated Press, the 32 team model is seen as advantageous as it offers "competitively balanced schedules and division alignments".<ref name=NFLAP5May2012/> CBS also argued that expansion teams generally struggle "for quite some time", suggesting a relocated team would be the better option from the standpoint of competitiveness.<ref name=CBS28October2012/>
Speaking in 2012, Goodell responded positively to the prospect of creating new teams through expansion "in the foreseeable future".<ref name=NFLAP5May2012/> It has been speculated that the current (2012) US market was saturated, and so it was unlikely that an expansion team within the US would generate the NFL's desired growth without a fundamental change in their funding model, such as the introduction of pay-per-view TV, which was also seen as unlikely since the league's current broadcasting contracts run to 2022.<ref name=NFLAP5May2012/>
===Shared franchise=== According to NFL.com, one possible way to achieve a London franchise in a way that overcomes the various issues facing a London operation, which has been considered by team owners and NFL executives, is the possibility of a shared franchise, with the team playing four home games in London and four in the US, although this was not considered ideal as it could potentially weaken the appeal given the split fanbase and ultimately not achieve critical mass, in addition it would be unlikely to be attractive to London fans if it were assumed in that scenario that any such team would always play its post-season games in its US base. Speaking in 2015, Waller stated "we've never had real discussions about a shared market".<ref name=NFL.com2October2015>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000547487/article/london-team-by-2022-nfl-continues-to-forge-forward-in-uk |title=London team by 2022? NFL continues to forge forward in U.K. |date=October 2, 2015 |author=NFL.com}}</ref>
===Relocating a franchise===
====Jacksonville Jaguars==== As the designated home team for the International Series, the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] are often mentioned as the most likely existing NFL team to relocate to London, leaving their current home of [[TIAA Bank Field]] in Florida.<ref name=CBS28October2012/><ref name=TheTelegraph2January2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/11322205/NFL-eye-Tottenhams-new-ground-as-home-for-London-based-American-Football-franchise.html |title=NFL eye Tottenham's new ground as home for London-based American Football franchise |date=January 2, 2015 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref> It is often pointed out in support that current Jaguars owner [[Shahid Khan]] is himself based in London, and also owns [[Fulham F.C.]] While Khan admits the move has been a success in terms of improving the finances and profile of what was a small and struggling franchise, he has nonetheless been reluctant to commit to a move, preferring the current arrangement.<ref name=BBCNews24October2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/34622055 |title=NFL: Jacksonville Jaguars' Shahid Khan not sold on London move |date=October 24, 2015 |author=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=BBCNews22October2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/34597937 |title=NFL extends Wembley deal to play two games a year until 2020 |date=October 22, 2015 |author=BBC News}}</ref>
On March 27, 2017, it was reported by [[City A.M.]] that the Jaguars are in discussion to build a permanent training facility near [[Wembley Stadium]].{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} If done, the team would be the first NFL franchise to have a training facility built outside of the U.S. On April 26, 2018 it was reported that Khan had made an offer to the [[The Football Association|FA]] to buy Wembley Stadium.,<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/apr/26/fa-sell-wembley-fulham-owner-shahid-khan</ref> although he subsequently rescinded that offer.
====Franchises with market knowledge==== As well as the Jacksonville Jaguars, the fact that some other existing franchises have owners with knowledge of the British market due to also owning United Kingdom based sports teams, such as the Glazer family's ownership of the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] based in [[Tampa, Florida]] and [[Glazer ownership of Manchester United|Manchester United]] leads to them being suggested as potential relocation candidates. Up until their move to Los Angeles was announced in January 2016, this also included the former [[Los Angeles Rams|St. Louis Rams]] owned by [[Arsenal F.C.]]'s majority shareholder, [[Stan Kroenke]].<ref name=BBCNews27September2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/29391069 |title=NFL Wembley: Seven years until London Jaguars? Rams? Raiders? |date=September 27, 2014 |author=BBC News}}</ref>
====Franchises with short leases==== The fact that the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] have a short term lease on its stadium is also often used to support media speculation that the franchise may be the one to relocate to London. This was also the case for the former [[Los Angeles Rams|St. Louis Rams]] and [[Los Angeles Chargers|San Diego Chargers]] until their respective moves to Los Angeles in 2016 and 2017 (even so, although the Rams will own their stadium and are almost certain to stay in Los Angeles for the long-term, the Chargers will be leasing a stadium and have not yet established a fan base, leaving open the possibility for another relocation),<ref>[https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/chargers-nfl-reportedly-considering-relocating-franchise-to-london-on-permanent-basis-amid-la-failures Chargers, NFL reportedly considering relocating franchise to London on permanent basis amid L.A. failures] by Will Brinson from CBS Sports, November 5, 2019</ref> and the [[Oakland Raiders]] until [[Oakland Raiders relocation to Las Vegas|relocation to Las Vegas]] was approved in 2017.<ref name=BBCNews27September2014/><ref name=Metro14January2016>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/01/14/what-does-the-rams-move-to-la-from-st-louis-mean-for-londons-nfl-franchise-hopes-5621839/ |title=What does the Rams move to LA from St Louis mean for London's NFL franchise hopes? |date=January 14, 2016 |author=Metro}}</ref>
The most immediate likely candidate for relocation is the [[Carolina Panthers]]. The cost to terminate the Panthers' agreement to use [[Bank of America Stadium]] after the 2018 season is relatively small, and the team's incoming owner, [[David Tepper]], does not have any significant ties to the Carolinas and has been tepid in his support of keeping the team in the region, stating upon assuming ownership in July 2018 "Charlotte is a logical place (... but) you're asking me too much. The only thing I have a market on right now is a lack of knowledge. I'll call it stupidity." <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/24049997/sale-panthers-david-tepper-finalized|title=Sale of Panthers to David Tepper finalized|last=Newton|first=David|date=9 July 2018|work=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref> Like the Raiders, the timing of the team's sale and stadium agreement is less than ideal, since the league does not intend to put a team in London on such short notice.
The Raiders, lacking a stadium for [[2019 Raiders season|2019]], were said to have an "extreme long shot" at playing all of their home games in London that year, should all other options fail. Cost and logistics concerns made this scenario unlikely, and the Raiders ultimately decided to renew their agreement with the [[Oakland Coliseum]] after initially stating they would not do so.<ref>[https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/raiders-most-likely-to-play-in-bay-area-in-2019-at-the-stadium-of-either-49ers-or-giants/ Raiders most likely to play in Bay Area in 2019 at the stadium of either 49ers or Giants]. ''CBS Sports''. Retrieved January 12, 2019.</ref>
====Weaker franchises==== As happened with the [[Buffalo Bills]] in 2014, even franchises with relatively long lease agreements but which are otherwise seen as struggling in their own market, are often named by the media as potential candidates for relocation to London, on the basis that those advocating relocation to a more lucrative market would be offering more money than those proposing to stay put. In the specific case of the Bills, it was however suggested that the NFL would oppose relocation since they were the only NFL team which played in New York state (the New York Jets and New York Giants being located in a shared stadium in New Jersey).<ref name=SBNation2June2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2014/6/2/5771714/buffalo-bills-sale-move-los-angeles-nfl |title=Buffalo Bills face potential move with upcoming sale |date=June 2, 2014 |author=SBNation}}</ref> The Bills' lease, which is effectively unbreakable in the short-term, has an exit window in 2019 and expires in 2022, coincidentally the same year as the NFL's target for a London franchise.
Countering one reason often cited as why the Jaguars would move, their low attendances, it has been argued that there are other franchises such as the Buccaneers with even lower attendances and less potential for growth in their own market in comparison.<ref name=CBS5June2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/writer/pete-prisco/22357404/why-not-london-bucs |title=Why not London Bucs? Don't assume Jaguars are moving |date=June 5, 2013 |author=CBS}}</ref>
===Multiple franchises=== Given the size of London, it has even been suggested by [[Atlanta Falcons]] owner Arthur Blank that there could ultimately be more than one franchise located in London, although not before a team in another European country.<ref name=NBC2June2014>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/06/02/arthur-blank-sees-maybe-more-than-one-nfl-team-in-london/ |title=Arthur Blank sees "maybe more than one" NFL team in London |date=June 2, 2014 |author=NBC}}</ref>
==Potential stadiums== One potential advantage for London as a market for an NFL franchise is that all of the likely stadiums for the franchise have already been built, with two of them being built in the 21st century and having sufficient modern amenities to host such a team. This eliminates the expense, currently over one billion United States dollars, of constructing a stadium for the team that meets NFL specifications.
===Wembley Stadium=== [[Wembley Stadium]], England's national football (soccer) stadium, was rebuilt and re-opened in 2007, and was the first venue for International Series games in that same year. It was built with locker rooms which are twice the size usually found in soccer venues, which allows them to accommodate a 53-man NFL roster.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
Wembley is expected to remain the exclusive venue until at least the second game of the 2016 programme (October 23). The stadium's owners, the [[Football Association]], are reportedly interested in using Wembley as the base of a London team, but it has been suggested by ''The Telegraph'' that they may struggle to accommodate a full programme of NFL games, as well as hosting the [[England national football team]]. Another potential issue is the natural grass pitch (following the first International Series game, the pitch was upgraded to a partly artificial [[Desso]] surface<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>) – England team manager [[Roy Hodgson]] having previously complained about the state of the surface after just two International Series games,<ref name=TheTelegraph2January2015/> claiming one player injured his ankle in 2014 because of the cut-up pitch.<ref name=TheTelegraph6November2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/11214977/Roy-Hodgson-fears-NFL-game-will-spoil-Wembley-pitch-ahead-of-Euro-2016-qualifer-against-Slovenia.html |title=Roy Hodgson fears NFL game will spoil Wembley pitch ahead of Euro 2016 qualifer [sic] against Slovenia |date=November 6, 2014 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref> The issue of NFL markings still being partly visible during soccer matches has also been criticised in the media.<ref name=TheTelegraph6November2014/>
To test the implications of a full season at Wembley, the NFL scheduled two International Series games over two weekends, followed by an England soccer game, to see how the surface copes.<ref name=BBCNews27September2014/> Wembley earns an estimated £500,000 to £1 million per NFL game in profit;{{r|TheTelegraph2January2015}} due to the debt incurred in building it, the BBC commented that maximising the number of other events staged at Wembley is vital to the FA's financial health, believing the benefit of the consistent revenue stream of 8 NFL games a year would not escape their attention. Although mindful of the calendar, according to the stadium's managing director speaking in 2013, "Football [(soccer)] is our priority but yes, I'm absolutely confident that if Roger Goodell wanted to have a franchise here, we could absolutely deliver on it."<ref name=BBCNews24September2013>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/24227296 |title=Why the NFL matters to Wembley Stadium's financial future |date=September 24, 2013 |author=BBC News}}</ref>
One possible method of accommodating the full schedule of an NFL franchise that the FA is investigating (as of 2014), is playing some home England fixtures at other football stadiums around the country, something which had not been done since the stadium had been reopened. A 10-year restriction on having to play all home games at Wembley expired in 2017, although Wembley remains the regular home of the team.<ref name=TheGuardian8October2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/08/england-hit-road-fa-wembley-nfl-franchise |title=England could hit the road as FA mulls idea of Wembley NFL franchise |date=October 8, 2014 |author=The Guardian}}</ref> Supporting the idea, the BBC contrasted the low attendances of some England soccer friendlies at Wembley, which reached a record low of 40,181 in 2014, surpassing the previous record of 48,876 in 2011, with the 80,000 crowds for the 2014 three game International Series.<ref name=BBCNews9October2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29546374 |title=England could play games around country if Wembley gets NFL team |date=October 9, 2014 |author=BBC News}}</ref>
In April 2018, Jaguars owner [[Shahid Khan]] placed a bid on Wembley Stadium in an effort to solidify the Jaguars' presence in the city;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000928676/article/jaguars-owner-places-offer-to-buy-wembley-stadium|title=Jaguars owner places offer to buy Wembley Stadium|work=NFL.com|first=Kevin|last=Patra|date=April 26, 2018|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> this offer was retracted in October 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45893325|title=Wembley: Shahid Khan withdraws 'divisive' offer to buy national stadium from FA|work=BBC News|date=October 18, 2018|accessdate=December 11, 2018}}</ref>
===Tottenham Hotspur Stadium=== On July 8, 2015 it was announced that the NFL had agreed to stage a minimum of two games a season for a ten-year period at [[Tottenham Hotspur Stadium|Tottenham Hotspur's new stadium in Northumberland Park]], which opened nearly a year behind schedule in 2019. This was interpreted as boosting the chances of an eventual London franchise.<ref name=BBCNews8July2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33442455 |title=Tottenham Hotspur will host NFL matches at new stadium |date=July 8, 2015 |author=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=BusinessInsider8July2015>{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/nfl-tottenham-stadium-deal-london-nfl-team-2015-7?r=US&IR=T |title=The NFL just got closer to putting a team in London |date=July 8, 2015 |author=Business Insider}}</ref> As a result of the deal, the stadium was specifically designed for both American and association versions of football. It has a retractable natural grass pitch over an artificial surface used for NFL games (which should allow both soccer and NFL games to be played on the same weekend<ref name=BusinessInsider8July2015/>), and with locker rooms of sufficient size to accommodate the 53-man size of an NFL team roster. Its proposed capacity of 61,000 was described a being more appropriate for the day-to-day requirements of an NFL franchise than Wembley's 84,000.<ref name=TheGuardian4August2015/><ref name=BusinessInsider8July2015/> It has been suggested the design will also eliminate the issue at Wembley whereby the lowest 5,000 seats cannot be used because spectator views of the pitch are obstructed by the various officials, coaches and players who stand on the sidelines during an NFL game.<ref name=TheTelegraph8July2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/11725998/Tottenham-close-to-signing-deal-with-NFL-to-stage-American-Football-matches-at-new-61000-seater-stadium.html |title=Tottenham sign deal with NFL to stage American Football matches at new 61,000-seater stadium |date=July 8, 2015 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref> The architect, [[Populous (company)|Populous]], had previously designed 14 NFL stadiums.<ref name=BusinessInsider8July2015/>
===Twickenham Stadium=== On November 3, 2015, the NFL also announced it had reached a deal with the [[Rugby Football Union]] to host a minimum of three games in three years at [[Twickenham Stadium]], beginning from the 2016 International Series. The deal is designed to be flexible, i.e. it could involve two fixtures in one year and none the next.<ref name=TheTelegraph3November2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/international/england/11971890/Twickenham-agrees-deal-to-stage-NFL-games.html |title=Twickenham agrees deal to stage NFL games |date=November 3, 2015 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref> The deal also includes an option to add two more games in the same period.<ref name=BBCNews3November2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/34707958 |title=NFL to play at Twickenham as three-year deal is announced |date=November 3, 2015 |author=BBC News}}</ref> The three-game commitment was fulfilled in two years. All three games were held in October, as the venue is home of the [[England national rugby union team|England national rugby team]] during the November test matches.
===Multiple stadiums=== To resolve some of the issues, it has also been suggested a London franchise may use more than one of the suggested venues as their home stadium.<ref name=TheTelegraph2January2015/>
==Issues== A number of issues need to be resolved before a London franchise can be set up; speaking in 2015 Waller stated "We feel very comfortable from a fan perspective, from a sponsor and a stadium perspective now, that we have all of the right things in place. The one thing that we’ve got to do more work on is how would it work from a team operational standpoint?"<ref name=NBC25September2015>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/09/25/before-putting-an-nfl-team-in-london-league-wants-to-check-logistics/ |title=Before putting an NFL team in London, league wants to check logistics |date=September 25, 2015 |author=NBC}}</ref>
===Logistics=== Speaking after talks with the UK government, [[Dan Marino]] argued that probably the biggest challenge facing a London franchise is the physical logistics of moving the staff and equipment across the Atlantic for every away game. To overcome this, he speculated that the NFL might follow the example of other sports like basketball and baseball, where some teams play away games in back to back series of three or four games, allowing the team to stay in the US for this part of their schedule.<ref name=BusinessReporter2October2015/> It has been noted that this approach may be problematic as it requires players to spend multiple weeks at a time away from home (whether home is in the US or London), something they would not have to do in a US based franchise. The NFL's use of a [[salary cap]] would also make using financial incentives to overcome this problematic.<ref name=TheGuardian28September2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2014/sep/28/london-nfl-franchise-work-sean-ingle |title=London looks increasingly likely to get NFL franchise but could it work? |date=September 28, 2014 |author=The Guardian}}</ref> For the 2018 season, the league aims to test the concept of one of the teams playing back-to-back games in London.<ref name="2022_target_doable">Breer, Albert (September 21, 2017). [https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/09/21/nfl-london-team-international-series-europe-football Game Plan: NFL Believes London is Ready for Team; 2022 Target is Doable]. ''SI.com''. Retrieved October 1, 2017.</ref>
===Off-season and training camp=== As well as the issue of a home stadium facility, the league has also been considering where a London franchise would hold their [[Training camp (National Football League)|training camp]], which begins in late July and normally involves several players not yet formally signed to the club. Similarly, another issue is whether or not it would have a base in the US for the off-season period, the gap between whenever their season ends until the start of the following training camp, in which the club will normally hold several meetings regarding staff and player contracts.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
As of 2014 the NFL had investigated the possibility of a London team establishing a permanent base in conjunction with a Premier League club, but it was considered unlikely for reasons of infrastructure and scheduling.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/> The league has also considered establishing a secondary base, probably in the [[Southeastern United States]], for the London club to use for circumstances when returning to London is impractical.<ref name=2022_target_doable/>
===Fanbase=== The NFL has set a target of reaching a total of 6 million "avid fans" in the UK before they will consider a London franchise viable, and surveys the UK annually to assess this figure; an avid fan being defined by the NFL as someone who says they're "extremely interested" in the NFL or that it is their favourite sport. Speaking during the 2015 International Series, Waller stated "We’re currently at four million, we were at about 2.3 million when the International Series started [in 2007]. We’re on track to reach that six million target by 2020."<ref name=TheTelegraph24October2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/americanfootball/11953250/London-NFL-team-needs-two-million-extra-fans.html |title=London NFL team needs two million extra fans |date=October 24, 2015 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref> Speaking at the start of 2016, he said "The fan base is big enough and passionate enough that it can support a franchise".<ref name=BBCNews20January2016>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/american-football/35360989 |title=NFL plans permanent UK-based franchise 'in six years' |date=January 20, 2016 |author=BBC News}}</ref>
It has been suggested that a significant stumbling block to creating the necessary fanbase is ironically the success of the NFL in promoting itself in the UK in the past. Many fans had been drawn into the NFL when the game was popularized in the 1980s, leading to evidence of support for all of the NFL's 32 teams in UK based fans, many of whom would be unlikely to support a London team as a first resort, i.e. being unlikely to consider them anything other than their favorite second team at best, and a potential rival at worst. As a result, while wishing to retain the support of anyone for a London team on a second favorite basis, the NFL's UK operation has been focussing on growing the fan base by reaching out to younger fans without an established allegiance, and others who are entirely new to the sport.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/><ref name=TheGuardian4August2015/> The NFL's UK operation has pointed to the success of the 1995 expansion team the [[Carolina Panthers]] having grown a fanbase in a previously untapped market to support the idea that a London team could do the same.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
In an attempt to gauge support for a London team, from the 2015 season the dates and times of the International Series games were adjusted to make them more closely resemble the home fixtures of a London team, as opposed to casting them as one off special events being timed in a fashion more convenient for a US audience.<ref name=TheGuardian4August2015/>
As of the 2014 International Series, 9 out of 10 tickets for the games were bought by people who live within three hours' travel of London, with 33,000 people choosing to buy a package ticket for all three games.<ref name=BBCNews27September2014/> That number had risen to 40,000 repeat customers for the four-game package in 2017.<ref name=2022_target_doable/>
The league has been encouraged by the fact that the International Series games were still attracting over 80,000 fans for a game like the [[2015 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] versus the [[2015 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] on October 31, 2015, the teams which had the 24th and 31st best records in the NFL at game time, leading ''The Telegraph'' to observe that [[2015–16 Middlesbrough F.C. season|Middlesbrough]] vs [[2015–16 Brentford F.C. season|Brentford]] would be the equivalent English soccer fixture on the day (based on their positions in the [[2015–16 Football League Championship|Football League Championship]]).<ref name=TheTelegraph31October2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/americanfootball/11967718/NFL-expansion-to-London-is-extraordinary-says-Leiweke.html |title=NFL expansion to London is 'extraordinary', says Leiweke |date=October 31, 2015 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref>
===League schedule=== The NFL and others have also recognised that the current arrangement of giving all teams that play an International Series game the following week off (a bye-week) as being impractical if a London franchise was created, leading to the need to either change the schedule, or persuade teams to play UK and US fixtures in adjacent weeks.<ref name=BBCNews27September2014/> The arrangement practised by the [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football|University of Hawaii football team]], separated from the [[Continental United States|U.S. mainland]] by about 3,900 km/2,400 miles, has been suggested as the model to follow for playing blocks of two to three games, home and away.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
While still retaining the bye-week, as a test of the logistics, the first game of the 2015 International Series was the first time teams only travelled to London for the weekend, having previously spent a whole week in the UK.<ref name=NFL.com2October2015/>
===Competitiveness=== The NFL is mindful of avoiding the perception that any potential London franchise was being established simply to increase the profile and revenue of the league; any team based in London must be competitive and be able to win the [[Super Bowl]].<ref name=BBCNews27September2014/>
The scheduling of the first back-to-back weekend fixtures in the 2015 International Series was also a test of a potential London franchise on competitiveness.<ref name=NFL.com2October2015/> One potential issue affecting competition that has been identified (by an NFL team owner) is what happens should a London franchise reach the post-season, which could possibly involve a long trip for a west coast based team to London, and then back to the US for the next weekend.<ref name=NFL.com2October2015/> In addition to the travel, it is believed this also presents a challenge in terms of potentially leaving away teams only a week to plan a foreign trip (in contrast to teams knowing the regular season schedule months in advance).<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
While the International Series fixtures have tested the effect on personnel of travelling east from the USA to the UK and then playing a game within a few days, because of the bye week it has yet to be established what the effect is when travelling the other way. It has been suggested this may be tested by scheduling one team to play back-to-back weekends in the International Series (as the notional home and away team).<ref name=NFL.com2October2015/>
Another issue considered is whether or not a London team would have an unfair competitive advantage compared to US-based teams, due to the extra distances away teams would have to travel to play them.<ref name=TheMMQB2October2014/>
===Tax=== As of 2013, players appearing in International Series games were subject to UK tax on their income and endorsements on a pro rata basis. If expanded to a full slate of regular season games, it has been suggested that unless the government granted exemptions to attract the NFL, which have been applied to some but not all sports/athletes, then the difference between the UK and US tax codes would be sufficient to dissuade players who are [[free agent]]s from signing for a London franchise.<ref name=ESPN25September2013/> The talks between the Chancellor and the NFL from 2014 onwards were interpreted by the media as a willingness to offer support in the form of promises of tax exemptions.<ref name=TheTelegraph22October2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/americanfootball/11181223/London-based-NFL-team-receives-boost-with-Chancellor-confirming-he-has-held-talks-over-a-Wembley-franchise.html |title=London-based NFL team receives boost with Chancellor confirming he has held talks over a Wembley franchise |date=October 22, 2014 |author=The Telegraph}}</ref>
===Visas=== As of 2013, players appearing in International Series games were admitted on temporary working visas, a situation which would not be possible for players working a full home schedule, which would require visas to be issued by a UK government recognised governing body for the sport. Although the British version of the game is administered by the [[British American Football Association]] (BAFA), it is not recognised by the UK government for visa purposes. In order to clear these obstacles, it has been suggested the NFL would either have to create its own governing body in the UK, or work through BAFA after they gain approval. Although not expected to fail, it has been speculated that approval of the governing body could be conditional on restrictions being placed on the activities of the NFL in the UK that would not apply to US teams, depending on the government's view of how the visas benefit sport in the country. Analogies have been drawn to soccer, where players from outside the [[European Union]] must be shown to be bringing something "special and different", and teams are required to comprise a minimum number of EU citizens. Individual visas may still also be denied due to issues such as criminal convictions.<ref name=ESPN25September2013/>
===European Union law=== As a member of the [[European Union]] (EU), much of the UK's laws are based on EU law. It has been suggested that the NFL's use of a draft system and a minimum age limit on players would come into conflict with the EU's laws regarding [[Freedom of movement for workers in the European Union|freedom of movement for workers]] and [[European Union competition law|competition]]. Citing sports lawyer Andrew Nixon, ESPN suggested in 2013 that while the draft may be permissible for the same reasons it is in the US, the age restriction had no US analogy, and so how it would be interpreted by the [[European Commission]] would be difficult to predict. The impact of the [[Bosman ruling]] on players contracts is also unclear. It also argued that while the UK government would have more interest in making adjustments to accommodate a London team, the EU as a whole would have less to gain by adjusting its laws. A suggested workaround of the team being based in the US and simply flying in for games, Nixon said this was "not something that has been done before and it is untested".<ref name=ESPN25September2013/>
On June 23, 2016, the UK [[2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum|voted]] to [[Brexit|leave]] the EU. A spokesperson for the NFL said that it was working closely with its UK offices and "monitoring" the situation closely.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/nfl-monitoring-situation-united-kingdom-great-britain-brexit-vote-062416|title=NFL 'monitoring' UK situation after Brexit vote|date=June 24, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 21, 2017}}</ref> Nonetheless, some speculation has led to keep NFL owners on alert if the UK goes into a [[recession]] following an exit from the EU.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2016/06/24/will-brexit-bench-nfl-nba-in-united-kingdom.html|title=Will Brexit Bench NFL, NBA In The United Kingdom?|first=Thomas|last=Barrabi|date=June 24, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 21, 2017}}</ref>
===Collective bargaining agreement=== Many aspects of NFL players' benefits and conditions are set down by the [[National Football League collective bargaining agreement]], negotiated by the [[National Football League Players Association]] (NFLPA), which could potentially impact the establishment of a London franchise.<ref name=NBCSports2October2013>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/10/02/nflpa-believes-it-can-block-a-move-to-london/ |title=NFLPA believes it can block a move to London |date=October 2, 2013 |author=NBC Sports}}</ref><ref name=TheObserver27September2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/sep/27/nfl-london-franchise-dallas-miami-oakland |title=London NFL franchise remains some way off, players’ union says |date=September 27, 2014 |author=The Observer}}</ref> Last negotiated in 2011, the current version runs until the 2020 season.
Speaking in September 2014, George Atallah, the NFLPA assistant executive director of external affairs, said of the issue that "A permanent team in London would require collective bargaining between the league and the players’ union and the NFL have not got to the point where they have said we want to raise it." and "Most players enjoy the experience of going over to London and from our perspective a team based in the UK could be viable – but only if the working conditions and health and safety aspects are satisfactory".<ref name=TheObserver27September2014/> This followed a 2013 comment that "Expanding to London by definition is a change in working conditions, placing the conversation squarely in the context of collective bargaining".<ref name=ESPN25September2013/>
NBC Sports has speculated that "It's possible that the NFLPA simply will never agree to a London move. If [they] realize that any of them could be traded to the London team, or could have a London-based team as their only option for ongoing NFL employment via free agency, keeping a team out of London would keep that from ever happening."<ref name=NBCSports2October2013/>

{{short description|One of two conferences in the National Football League}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox sports conference|title=American Football Conference|league=[[National Football League]]|logo=American Football Conference logo.svg|caption=American Football Conference logo (2010–present)|pixels=150 px|formerly=[[American Football League]] (AFL)|sport=[[American football]]|founded=1970|teams=16|most_champs=[[New England Patriots]] (11 titles)|champion=[[New England Patriots]] (11th title)}} The '''American Football Conference''' ('''AFC''') is one of the two [[Conference (sports)|conferences]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL), the highest professional level of American football in the United States. This conference and its counterpart the [[National Football Conference]] (NFC), currently contain 16 teams organized into 4 [[Division (sport)|divisions]]. Both conferences were created as part of the [[AFL–NFL merger|1970 merger]] with the rival [[American Football League]] (AFL), with all ten of the former AFL teams and three NFL teams forming the AFC, and the remaining thirteen NFL clubs forming the NFC. A series of league expansions and division realignments have occurred since the merger, thus making the current total of 16 clubs in each conference. The current AFC champions are the [[New England Patriots]], who defeated the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] in the 2018 [[AFC Championship Game]] for their 11th conference championship. ==Current teams== Since 2002, like the NFC, the AFC has 16 teams, organized into 4 [[Division (sport)|divisions]] each with four teams: [[AFC East|East]], [[AFC North|North]], [[AFC South|South]] and [[AFC West|West]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/25549819/2019-nfl-pro-bowl-selections-all-32-teams-full-nfc-afc-rosters|title=2019 Pro Bowl selections for every team: Full NFC, AFC rosters|date=2018-12-19|website=ESPN.com|language=en|access-date=2019-02-23}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/17/sports/football/parity-afc-becomes-a-conference-of-haves-and-have-nots.html|title=Parity? This chart of the [[2018 NFL season#Regular season standings|2018 season standings]] displays an application of the NFL scheduling formula. The [[2018 New England Patriots season|Patriots in 2018]] (highlighted in green) finished in first place in the [[AFC East]]. Thus, [[2019 New England Patriots season|in 2019]], the Patriots will play two games against each of its division rivals (highlighted in light blue), one game against each team in the [[AFC North]] and [[NFC East]] (highlighted in yellow), and one game each against the first-place finishers in the [[AFC South]] and [[AFC West]] (highlighted in orange).
Currently, the thirteen opponents each team faces over the 16-game regular season schedule are set using a pre-determined formula:{{cite web|title=2012 Opponents Determined|url=http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/2012-opponents-determined.pdf|publisher=[[National Football League|NFL]]|accessdate=January 23, 2012|date=January 2, 2012}} Each AFC team plays the other teams in their respective division twice (home and away) during the regular season, in addition to 10 other games assigned to their schedule by the NFL. Two of these games are assigned on the basis of a particular team's final divisional standing from the previous season. The remaining 8 games are split between the roster of two other NFL divisions. This assignment shifts each year and will follow a standard cycle. Using the 2012 regular season schedule as an example, each team in the AFC West plays against every team in the AFC North and NFC South. In this way, non-divisional competition will be mostly among common opponents – the exception being the two games assigned based on the team's prior-season divisional standing. At the end of each season, the four division winners and two [[wild card (sports)|wild cards]] (non-division winners with best regular season record) in the AFC qualify for the [[National Football League playoffs|playoffs]]. The AFC playoffs culminate in the [[AFC Championship Game]] with the winner receiving the [[Lamar Hunt]] Trophy. The AFC Champion then plays the [[National Football Conference|NFC]] Champion in the [[Super Bowl]]. ==History== [[File:Oldafclogo.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Original American Football Conference logo, based on the AFL logo with blue stars]] Both the AFC and the NFC were created after the NFL [[AFL–NFL merger|merged]] with the [[American Football League]] (AFL) in 1970.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldalmanacforkids.com/WAKI-ViewArticle.aspx?pin=x-fo055624a&article_id=608&chapter_id=13&chapter_title=Sports&article_title=Pro_Football_History|title=Pro Football – History|access-date=April 3, 2009}} The AFL began play in 1960 with eight teams, and added two more expansion clubs (the [[Miami Dolphins]] in 1966 and the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in 1968) before the merger. In order to equalize the number of teams in each conference, three NFL teams that predated the AFL's launch (the [[Cleveland Browns]], [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], and the then-[[Baltimore Colts]]) joined the ten former AFL teams to form the AFC. The two AFL divisions [[AFL East]] and [[AFL West]] were more or less intact, while the NFL's Century Division, in which the Browns and the Steelers had played since 1967, was moved from the NFL to become the new AFC Central. Upon the completion of the merger of the AFL and NFL in 1970, the newly-minted American Football Conference had already agreed upon their divisional setup along mostly geographical lines for the [[1970 NFL season|1970 season]]; the National Football Conference, however, could not agree upon their setup, and one was chosen from a fishbowl on January 16, 1970. Since the merger, five expansion teams have joined the AFC and two have left, thus making the current total 16. When the [[Seattle Seahawks]] and the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] joined the league in 1976, they were temporarily placed in the NFC and AFC respectively. This arrangement lasted for one season only before the two teams switched conferences. The Seahawks eventually returned to the NFC as a result of the [[2002 NFL season#Expansion and realignment|2002 realignment]]. The expansion [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] joined the AFC in 1995. There have been five teams that have relocated at least once. In 1984, the [[History of the Baltimore Colts|Baltimore Colts]] [[Baltimore Colts relocation to Indianapolis|relocated]] to Indianapolis. In 1995, the [[Cleveland Browns]] had attempted to move to Baltimore; the resulting [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy|dispute]] between Cleveland and the team led to Modell establishing the [[Baltimore Ravens]] with the players and personnel from the Browns, while the Browns were placed in suspended operations before they were reinstated by the NFL. The Ravens were treated as an expansion team. In California, the [[Oakland Raiders]] relocated to Los Angeles in 1982, and back to Oakland in 1995, while the [[History of the San Diego Chargers|San Diego Chargers]] returned to Los Angeles in 2017 after 56 years in San Diego. The [[History of the Houston Oilers|Houston Oilers]] moved to [[Tennessee]] in 1997, where they were renamed the Tennessee Oilers. The team would change its name again, two years later, to the [[Tennessee Titans]]. The NFL would again expand in 2002, adding the [[Houston Texans]] to the AFC. With the exception of the aforementioned relocations since that time, the divisional setup has remained static ever since. Between 1995 and 2018, the AFC has sent less than half of the 16 AFC teams to the [[Super Bowl]] with only 7 of the 16 individual teams making it. [[New England Patriots]] (10 times), [[Denver Broncos]] (4 times), [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] (4 times), [[Baltimore Ravens]] (2 times), [[Indianapolis Colts]] (2 times), [[Oakland Raiders]] (1 time), and [[Tennessee Titans]] (1 time). By contrast, the [[National Football Conference|NFC]] has sent 13 of the 16 NFC teams during that same time frame with only the [[Detroit Lions]], [[Minnesota Vikings]], and [[Washington Redskins]] missing out on an appearance in the [[Super Bowl]]. 16 of the last 18 AFC champions have started one of just three quarterbacks - [[Tom Brady]], [[Peyton Manning]], and [[Ben Roethlisberger]] - in the Super Bowl. The AFC has started 5 quarterbacks in the last 18 Super Bowls, while the NFC has started 14. ==Logo== [[Image:American Football Conference logo old.svg|right|thumb|2nd American Football Conference logo used from 1970 to 2009|216x216px]] The merged league created a new logo for the AFC that took elements of the old AFL logo, specifically the "A" and the six stars surrounding it. The AFC logo basically remained unchanged from 1970 to 2009. The 2010 NFL season introduced an updated AFC logo, with the most notable revision being the removal of two stars (leaving four representing the four divisions of the AFC), and moving the stars inside the letter, similar to the NFC logo.{{cite web|url=http://www.uniwatchblog.com/2010/03/02/but-i-absolutely-refuse-to-write-about-the-draft-caps/ |title=But I Absolutely Refuse to Write About the Draft Caps |author=Paul Lukas |publisher=Uni Watch blog |access-date=April 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100506134900/http://www.uniwatchblog.com/2010/03/02/but-i-absolutely-refuse-to-write-about-the-draft-caps/ |archivedate=May 6, 2010 |url-status=dead }} ==Television== [[NFL on NBC|NBC]] aired the AFC's Sunday afternoon and playoff games from 1970 through the 1997 season. From 1998 to 2013, [[NFL on CBS|CBS]] was the primary broadcast rightsholder to the AFC. Since 2014, select AFC games are cross-flexed from CBS to [[Fox NFL|Fox]]. Since 1990, select AFC playoff games have aired on ABC or ESPN. ==References== {{reflist}} {{NFL}} {{Navboxes|list= {{Baltimore Ravens}} {{Buffalo Bills}} {{Cincinnati Bengals}} {{Cleveland Browns}} {{Denver Broncos}} {{Houston Texans}} {{Indianapolis Colts}} {{Jacksonville Jaguars}} {{Kansas City Chiefs}} {{Los Angeles Chargers}} {{Miami Dolphins}} {{New England Patriots}} {{New York Jets}} {{Oakland Raiders}} {{Pittsburgh Steelers}} {{Tennessee Titans}} }} [[Category:National Football League]] [[Category:American Football League|Conference]] [[Category:Sports organizations established in 1970]]

{{Lead too short|date=September 2016}} The [[National Football League]] (NFL) is the premier [[professional football (gridiron)|professional]] [[American football]] league in the United States, and is also one of the [[major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major North American professional sports leagues]]. However, the NFL is not without its share of controversies. Throughout history, everything from questionable championship rulings to team relocation decisions to allegedly criminal behavior by players has been part of the conversation surrounding the NFL. Many of the recent controversies have surrounded NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]], player conduct,<ref>{{cite web|last=Doyel |first=Gregg |url=http://www.cbssports.com/columns/story/13243927/goodells-conduct-policy-veering-from-mostly-right-to-all-wrong |title=Goodell's conduct policy veering from mostly right to all wrong |publisher=CBSSports.com |date=2010-04-18 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> and/or the league's role in player safety.<ref>{{cite web|first=Clifton |last=Brown |url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/nfl/story/2012-05-08/can-safety-violence-co-exist-nfl-faces-daunting-future |title=NFL concussion conundrum: Can safety, violence co-exist? Challenge is daunting – NFL – Sporting News |publisher=AOL.SportingNews.com |date=2012-05-08 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
==1925 NFL Championship== {{main|1925 NFL Championship controversy}}
The 1925 NFL Championship, officially held by the [[History of the Chicago Cardinals|Chicago Cardinals]], has been the subject of controversy since it was awarded. Under the league rules during that time, the NFL title was automatically given to the team with the best record at the end of the season instead of having the winner be determined by a playoff tournament. There was an open-ended schedule during that season; although the final listed league games ended on December 6, teams could still schedule contests against each other through December 20 to make more money.
The [[Pottsville Maroons]] were one of the dominant teams of the [[1925 NFL season|1925 season]], and after defeating the Cardinals on December 6, came away with the best record in the league. However, NFL commissioner [[Joseph Carr]] suspended and removed the Maroons from the NFL after they played an unauthorized exhibition game in [[Philadelphia]], on the grounds that they had violated the territorial rights of the [[Frankford Yellow Jackets]]. The Cardinals played and won two more games against weak NFL opponents, giving them a superior record, and were awarded the title.
Pottsville supporters argue that the suspension was illegitimate, and that the Maroons, who were reinstated the next year, would have had the superior record had they not been suspended. Others{{Who|date=September 2015}} claim that Chicago was the legitimate champions based on the rules of the time. The NFL has investigated Pottsville's case on two occasions, both times upholding its decision that the Cardinals are the 1925 champions.
==Team relocation controversies== {{main|National Football League franchise moves and mergers}}
===Baltimore Colts move to Indianapolis=== {{main|Baltimore Colts relocation to Indianapolis}} The [[Baltimore Colts]] were moved to [[Indianapolis]] by owner [[Robert Irsay]] in 1984, after multiple years of lobbying to renovate or replace the decrepit [[Memorial Stadium (Baltimore)|Memorial Stadium]], including talks of a "Baltodome".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u5sKmJItUF4C&pg=PA112 |title=Glory for Sale: Fans, Dollars, and the New NFL – Jon Morgan – Google Books |date=1995-11-06 |accessdate=2012-07-21|isbn=9780963124654 |last1=Morgan |first1=Jon }}</ref> In 1982, the Hoosier Dome (later called the [[RCA Dome]]) was built in Indianapolis, increasing interest in a move by the Colts. Eventually, the Colts moved to Indianapolis with the help of the moving company [[Mayflower Transit]], who did so at night to confuse the [[Maryland State Police]] and fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bonesaw.tripod.com/Indy_History.htm |title=History of the Indianapolis Colts |publisher=Bonesaw.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
===Cleveland Browns move to Baltimore=== {{main|Cleveland Browns relocation controversy}} [[Cleveland Browns]] owner [[Art Modell]] decided to move the Browns to [[Baltimore]], 12 years after the Colts moved away from the city. After backlash from the fans,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/sports/pro-football-a-city-fights-to-save-the-browns.html?ref=art_modell&pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first=Richard | last=Sandomir | title=PRO FOOTBALL;A City Fights To Save The Browns | date=1995-11-12}}</ref> the team and the NFL decided on a special compromise: Modell could relocate the Browns to Baltimore, but would play as an "expansion team", and the Browns will go into a state of "suspended operations". Modell's new team would eventually be named the [[Baltimore Ravens]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/04/sports/football-baltimore-browns-may-be-a-done-deal.html?src=pm | work=The New York Times | first=Timothy W. | last=Smith | title=FOOTBALL;Baltimore Browns May Be a Done Deal | date=1995-11-04}}</ref> In 1999, the Cleveland Browns returned to the league as an [[expansion team]]. Similar agreements would eventually be used for the [[Seattle SuperSonics]] of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] in their [[Seattle SuperSonics relocation to Oklahoma City|relocation to Oklahoma City]] to become the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nba/2008127774_websoni20.html | work=The Seattle Times | first=Jeff | last=Latzke | title=Seattle to retain SuperSonics banners and trophies | date=2008-08-20}}</ref> along with the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] in their move to become the [[Houston Dynamo]] (a new Earthquakes team eventually returned).<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/mls/quakes/2005-12-15-relocation-houston_x.htm | work=USA Today | title=San Jose's MLS team moving to Houston | date=2005-12-15}}</ref>
===St. Louis Rams move to Los Angeles=== On April 13, 1995, [[Stan Kroenke]] helped [[Georgia Frontiere]] move the [[History of the Los Angeles Rams|Los Angeles Rams]] from [[Anaheim]] to [[St. Louis]] by purchasing a 30% share of the team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-04-13/news/mn-54268_1_rams-owner|title=NFL Owners OK Rams' Move to St. Louis|date=13 April 1995|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
In April 2010, as a majority stock holder, Kroenke said: "I'm going to attempt to do everything that I can to keep the Rams in St. Louis. Just as I did everything that I could to bring the team to St. Louis in 1995. I believe my actions speak for themselves."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/columns/from-the-archives-kroenke-s-pledge-to-keep-the-rams/article_3b49e97d-2799-50aa-8b7b-5a82bf5d5a4b.html|title=Kroenke's pledge to keep the Rams in St. Louis|date=21 April 2010|work=St. Louis Post Dispatch|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
In August 2010, [[Stan Kroenke]] purchased the Rams using a [[Right of first refusal]] clause in the last minute of bidding, beating a high bid from [[Shahid Khan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=5496516|title=Stan Kroenke is new Rams owner|date=25 August 2010|work=ESPN|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
In February 2013, the Rams and the City of St. Louis went to arbitration over a clause in the Rams lease that stated the Rams current stadium must be in the top tier of NFL Stadiums. The arbitrators agreed with the Rams, giving the Rams the ability to break their original lease and go to a year to year lease agreement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/02/02/rams-win-stadium-arbitration/|title=Rams win stadium arbitration|work=nbcsports.com|date=2013-02-02}}</ref> On January 5, 2015, it was announced that the [[Kroenke Sports & Entertainment|Kroenke Group]] was teaming up with [[Stockbridge Capital Group]] to build [[SoFi Stadium|a 70,000 seat NFL stadium]] and venue in [[Inglewood, California]], a suburb of Los Angeles, threatening the Rams' future in St. Louis. In response, St. Louis countered with [[National Car Rental Field]], a proposed open-air stadium in the north riverfront in downtown St. Louis with the hope of the Rams staying in St. Louis.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Farmer|first1=Sam|last2=Vincent|first2=Roger|title=Owner of St. Louis Rams plans to build NFL stadium in Inglewood|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-0105-nfl-la-stadium-20150105-story.html#page=1|accessdate=5 January 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=5 January 2015}}</ref> The fanbase in St. Louis felt it was not being treated fairly—in 2014 the St. Louis Rams had 86% attendance despite a 6-10 record and 10 prior years of non-win seasons,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/attendance/_/year/2014 |title=2014 NFL Football Attendance – National Football League |website=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-12}}</ref> forcing fans and local sportswriters to question the integrity of the [[National Football League|NFL]] and Kroenke for even considering the Los Angeles plans.<ref name="stl5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/television/dan-caesar/st-louis-fans-praised-for-supporting-lousy-rams/article_2b127819-ca4d-5aa2-8465-8ca67cd89e13.html|first=Dan|last=Caesar|work=[[St. Louis Post Dispatch]]|title=St. Louis fans praised for supporting lousy Rams|date=2015-02-15|accessdate=2015-02-15}}</ref> St. Louis officials felt they were not receiving fair treatment either as Kroenke had no talks or discussions with city officials, who have expressed interest in keeping the team in St. Louis. In a radio interview, Kroenke was labeled as "enemy number one" in his home state due to his uncanny willingness to cooperate.<ref name="stl6">{{Cite news|url=http://kfwbam.com/2015/01/06/stl-mayors-office-would-welcome-the-chargers-or-raiders-if-rams-leave/|first=Fred|last=Roggin|work=The Beast 980|title=StL Mayor's Office would welcome the Chargers or Raiders if Rams leave|date=2015-06-15|accessdate=2015-06-15}}</ref> NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell also stated that St. Louis funding did not meet the criteria set by the NFL, even though St. Louis offered a stadium plan lacking 100 million dollars, but then ultimately gave 300m to Oakland and San Diego for their markets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/goodell-million-for-st-louis-stadium-fundamentally-inconsistent-with-nfl/article_1c529334-4e3f-5885-9f68-156184f56ad8.html|title=Goodell: $300 million for St. Louis stadium 'fundamentally inconsistent' with NFL policy|first=David|last=Hunn|work=stltoday.com}}</ref> On January 4, 2016, all three teams applied for relocation to Los Angeles for the [[2016 NFL season]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-0105-nfl-la-stadium-20150105-story.html#page=1|accessdate=January 5, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 11, 2015 | title=Owner of St. Louis Rams plans to build NFL stadium in Inglewood}}</ref> The following day, the Rams and Stan Kroenke released their proposal for relocation. Some of the Rams' conclusions were disputed by the [[Mayor of St. Louis]] [[Francis Slay]] (in a letter to [[Roger Goodell]]),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/slay-to-goodell-i-cannot-ever-remember-meeting-stan-kroenke/article_230c08b7-e9b1-5ab9-9a6f-e95f98fec761.html|accessdate=January 7, 2015|work=St. Louis Post Dispatch|date=January 7, 2016 | title=Slay to Goodell: I cannot ever remember meeting Stan Kroenke.}}</ref> The [[St. Louis Regional Chamber]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/st-louis-to-kroenke-you-re-preposterous/article_de93465b-0da2-52a2-b578-719eec790533.html|accessdate=January 7, 2015|work=St. Louis Post Dispatch|date=January 7, 2016 | title=St. Louis to Kroenke: You're 'preposterous'.}}</ref> and ''[[Forbes]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2016/01/06/stan-kroenkes-bad-relocation-math/|accessdate=January 7, 2015|work=St. Louis Post Dispatch|date=January 6, 2016 | title=Stan Kroenke's Bad Relocation Math.}}</ref>
On January 12, 2016, the NFL approved the Rams' application to relocate from St. Louis back to Los Angeles with a 30-2, although the move was generally considered malicious by fans in St. Louis citing how the NFL had its hand in the pot the whole time and St. Louis had a stadium plan in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14558668/st-louis-rams-relocate-los-angeles|title=Rams headed back to Los Angeles; Chargers have option to join|date=13 January 2016|work=ESPN|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Jim|title=NFL owners thrilled by Kroenke's move|url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/football/professional/nfl-owners-thrilled-by-kroenke-s-move/article_09762b03-a87e-5c6b-a9fa-250bb46450ae.html|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref>
The following day, officials were pondering [[Stan Kroenke]]'s removal from the [[Missouri Sports Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kmov.com/story/30947695/missouri-sports-hall-of-fame-mulling-kroenkes-removal|title=Missouri Sports Hall of Fame mulling Kroenke's removal|date=13 January 2016|work=KMOV|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref>
The initial $200 million as a standard part of the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s G4 stadium loan, plus the additional $100 requested from St. Louis totaled $300 million which the NFL ultimately deemed inadequate, was then granted to [[Oakland]] and [[San Diego]] to maintain their respected teams.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Florio|first1=Mike|title=Goodell reminds San Diego that $300 million is available for stadium|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2016/01/29/goodell-reminds-san-diego-that-300-million-is-available-for-stadium/|publisher=NBC Sports|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref>
On January 14, 2016, at a [[St. Louis Blues]] game, the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] Owner and Blues Owner dropped a puck together to celebrate the "best sports city in America", as the crowd chanted "Kroenke sucks!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nhl/story/_/id/14572783/st-louis-blues-fans-chant-kroenke-sucks-amid-ceremonial-puck-drop|title=St. Louis fans chant 'Kroenke sucks' amid ceremonial puck drop|date=14 January 2016|work=KMOV|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref>
It was reported by many sources that the Rams, although changing their name and city to Los Angeles, were still trying to get players to sign contracts with Missouri as the state of their employer, suspected in part with the relaxed Workers Rights laws in Missouri vs. the much stricter California laws. The NFL Players union has told all agents to not accept any contracts until the verbiage is changed for the Rams to be a California employer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/03/stan-kroenke-rams-move-to-los-angeles-workers-compensation|title=The Rams just hit St. Louis with the worst slap in the face yet|date=12 March 2016|work=USAToday.com|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref>
On March 14, 2016 prior St. Louis Rams COO [[Kevin Demoff]], expressed gratitude for the St. Louis Rams going on a losing streak in 2015 to give the relocation team more time to calculate a move to LA quoted with saying - "we went on a four game losing streak in the middle of November. So, we went from being in the playoff hunt and having a seed to out of the playoff hunt. That allowed us to have more time to talk about this, to put things together."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox2now.com/2016/03/14/fans-shocked-to-hear-demoff-happy-about-st-louis-rams-losing-season/|title=Fans shocked to hear Demoff happy about St. Louis Rams' losing season|date=14 March 2016|work=fox2now.com|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref>
Demoff, who was born in Los Angeles, joined the St. Louis Rams in 2009 just weeks before Stan Kroenke gained majority leader. Demoff also ran the [[Los Angeles Avengers]], an Arena Football league in Los Angeles in the early 2000s. Demoff was quoted as saying - "the league has handed Stan and the Rams their greatest opportunity in the last two decades: entry into L.A." suggesting the league had a large role in the relocation process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2016/04/04/Forty-Under-40/Kevin-Demoff.aspx|title=Forty Under 40: Kevin Demoff|date=4 April 2016|work=sportsbusinessdaily.com|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref>
On April 12, 2017 it was reported that the City of [[St. Louis]], [[St. Louis County, Missouri|St. Louis County]], and the [[Regional Convention and Sports Complex Authority]] filed a 52-page lawsuit against the [[NFL]] and all 32 NFL clubs as defendants (including Stan Kroenke) and seeks damages and restitution of profits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/football/professional/st-louis-suing-nfl-over-rams-relocation/article_501e2349-c9c9-5a70-9743-2583f89948d9.html|title=St. Louis suing NFL over Rams' relocation|date=12 April 2017|work=USAToday.com|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref>
==Player conduct== {{main|National Football League player conduct controversy}} In 2007, [[Roger Goodell]] became commissioner, and instituted a player conduct policy to help control off-field behavior by players.<ref name="Goodell strengthens">[[Associated Press]]. [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2007-04-10-new-conduct-policy_N.htm?csp=34 Goodell strengthens NFL player conduct policy] ''USA Today'', April 10, 2007.</ref> Various amounts of criticism were aimed at Goodell, who was known for stripping teams of draft picks, as well as criticizing the punishments for Adam Jones and Chris Henry, despite [[Adam Jones (American football)|Adam Jones]] not being convicted.<ref name=USATodaySports>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2007-04-10-new-conduct-policy_N.htm?csp=34 | work=[[USA Today]] | title=Goodell strengthens NFL personal conduct policy | date=2007-04-11}}</ref>
{{quote|The problem with the NFL's conduct policy is that it was designed not to halt off-field troubles as much as to squelch a looming public relations disaster that came after players like [[Tank Johnson]] and [[Adam Jones (American football)|Pacman Jones]] were arrested two years ago. The policy was not an iron-clad set of rules and consequences but rather a fluid concept in which Commissioner Roger Goodell hands out punishment on a case-by-case basis.|source=''[[The Washington Post]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/409221-the-hypocrisy-that-is-roger-goodell-and-the-nfl-player-conduct-policy |title=The Hypocrisy That Is Roger Goodell and the NFL Player Conduct Policy |website=Bleacher Report |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>}}

===Minnesota Vikings boat party scandal=== {{main|Minnesota Vikings boat party scandal}} On [[Lake Minnetonka]] in 2005, 17 [[Minnesota Vikings]] players ([[Daunte Culpepper]], [[Fred Smoot]], [[Mewelde Moore]], [[Pat Williams (American football)|Pat Williams]], [[Bryant McKinnie]], [[Nate Burleson]], [[Ralph Brown (cornerback)|Ralph Brown]], [[Troy Williamson]], [[Travis Taylor (American football)|Travis Taylor]], [[Kevin Williams (defensive tackle)|Kevin Williams]], [[Jermaine Wiggins]], [[Lance Johnstone]], [[Moe Williams]], [[Ken Irvin]], and [[Willie Offord]]) were accused of throwing a [[Group sex#Sex parties|sex party]] on a boat, with most of the players partaking in [[sexual intercourse]]. Fred Smoot was allegedly the ringleader of the party, and allegedly pushed a double-headed [[dildo]] into the [[vagina]]s of two women who were lying on the floor in the lounge area. After one of them left the party, he continued to "manipulate the dildo" inside the other woman.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/vikings/2005-12-15-boat-party-charges_x.htm|title= Culpepper, three other Vikings charged in boat-party scandal |work=USA Today |accessdate=2005-12-15 | first=Jeff | last=Baenen}}</ref> Later, on October 19, 2005, Vikings owner [[Zygi Wilf]], in a reportedly profanity-laced tirade, threatened to remove players from the roster who were involved in the planning of the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2198052&CMP=OTC-DT9705204233 |title=Report: Wilf delivers profanity-laced address to Vikings – NFL|publisher=ESPN |date=2005-10-19 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> Eventually, Culpepper, McKinnie, Smoot and Moe Williams were charged with indecent, disorderly, and lascivious conduct.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/vikings/2005-12-15-boat-party-charges_x.htm | work=USA Today | first=Jeff | last=Baenen | title=Culpepper, three other Vikings charged in boat-party scandal | date=2005-12-18}}</ref>
===Michael Vick investigation=== {{main|Bad Newz Kennels dog fighting investigation}} {{details|Timeline of the Bad Newz Kennels dog fighting investigation}} {{wikinews|NFL star Michael Vick indicted for running dog fighting operation}} [[File:Michael Vick, November 2006 (728).jpg|upright|thumb|left|Investigators said that [[Michael Vick]]'s dog fighting ring started in 2001 when he bought his house, and continued through 2007.]] In 2006, [[Atlanta Falcons]] quarterback [[Michael Vick]] was involved in a [[Dog fighting in the United States|dog fighting]] ring, and over seventy dogs, with most of them being [[pit bull terrier]]s, with some said to be showing signs of injuries, were seized, along with physical evidence during several searches of Vick's {{convert|15|acre|m2|adj=on}} property by local, state and federal authorities. During the investigation, Vick was revealed to be working with 4 others (Tony Taylor, Purnell Anthony Peace, Quanis Lavell Philips, and Oscar Allen). Eventually, they were convicted for "Conspiracy in interstate commerce/aid of unlawful animal cruelty venture". On September 13, Vick tested positive for [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], and was ordered by federal judge Henry E. Hudson to "submit to any method of testing required by the pretrial services officer or the supervising officer for determining whether the defendant is using a prohibited substance", and before getting sent to prison, Vick was placed under [[house arrest]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Vick Fails Drug Test, Under House Arrest | url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/law/09/26/vick/index.html | publisher=CNN | date=2007-09-26 }}</ref> After spending time at Northern Neck Regional Jail in [[Warsaw, Virginia]] awaiting his trial, on December 10, Vick was given 23 months in federal prison, followed by 3 years of probation. Vick was later placed in [[United States Penitentiary, Leavenworth]] until 2009. Vick was later released by the Falcons, and signed with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Vick, Eagles agree to 2-year deal |publisher=ESPN |date=2009-08-14 |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4397938 |accessdate=2009-08-28}}</ref>
===Banned substances=== {{further|Steroid use in American football}} Players' usage of [[anabolic steroid|steroids]] has been forbidden by the league since 1987, with players testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs being suspended without pay for four games for the first offense (a quarter of the regular season), eight games for a second offense (half of the regular season), and 12 months for a third offense.<ref name="Banned">{{cite web|url=http://www.nflpa.org/pdfs/RulesAndRegs/BannedSubstances.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624231704/http://www.nflpa.org/pdfs/RulesAndRegs/BannedSubstances.pdf|archivedate=June 24, 2008|title=NFLPA.org|publisher=NFLPA.org|accessdate=May 3, 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref> This policy has been praised by some<ref name="Apr28">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21734-2005Apr28.html |title=NFL's Steroid Policy Gets Kudos on Capitol Hill |work=The Washington Post |date=April 28, 2005 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 | first1=Mark | last1=Maske | first2=Leonard | last2=Shapiro}}</ref> and criticized by others.<ref name="CBS">{{cite news|author=Joel Roberts |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/04/27/national/main691147_page3.shtml |title=NFL Steroid Policy 'Not Perfect', House Committee Praises Tougher Testing Policy, But Still May Act – CBS News |publisher=CBSNews.com |date=April 27, 2005 |accessdate=May 3, 2010}}</ref> In 2006, former [[San Diego Chargers]] player [[Shawne Merriman]] tested positive for steroids, and was given a 4-game suspension. The incident later led to the "Merriman Rule", forbidding players who tested positive for PEDs from participating in the [[Pro Bowl]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_5172209 |title=Chargers LB supports the "Merriman Rule" |work=Denver Post |date= 2007-02-07|accessdate=2012-07-21 |first=Mike |last=Klis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2754079 |title=Sources: Positive 'roids test to result in Pro Bowl ban |publisher=ESPN |date=2007-02-04 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> Another popular drug in recent years amongst players has been the emergence of the amphetamine [[Adderall]]. Multiple players, particularly [[defensive back]]s, have been suspended for testing positive for the substance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/adderall-nfls-new-trendy-ped-drug-steroids-112912|title=Adderall: NFL's new, trendy PED - FOX Sports|date=29 November 2012|work=foxsports.com}}</ref> Adderall is believed to heighten focus and attention and to allow for quicker thought and reaction time, potentially giving a player an advantage.
On December 27, 2015, [[Al Jazeera America]] released [[The Dark Side: Secrets of the Sports Dopers|a report]] conducted by the [[Al Jazeera America#Al Jazeera Investigative Unit|Al Jazeera Investigative Unit]] investigating professional athletes' use of [[Performance-enhancing drugs]] (PEDs) which named [[Peyton Manning]], among other prominent athletes, as having received illegal drugs from Charles Sly, a pharmacist who had worked at the Guyer Anti-Aging Clinic in Indianapolis during the fall of 2011. The report involved Liam Collins, a British hurdler, going undercover in an attempt to obtain banned substances from Sly and other medical professionals. The report claimed that Manning's wife, Ashley, had been shipped [[Off-label use|off-label]] [[Growth hormone|human growth hormone]] (HGH) by the Guyer Institute during the fall of 2011 while Manning was out with a severe neck injury, with the intention of hiding that Manning was the one actually receiving the drugs.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/dark-side-secrets-sports-dopers-151227133355144.html |title=The dark side: The secret world of sports doping |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14441114/documentary-links-peyton-manning-other-pro-athletes-use-peds |title=Documentary links Peyton Manning, other pro athletes to use of PEDs |website=Espn.go.com |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite being made against Peyton Manning | ProFootballTalk |website=Profootballtalk.nbcsports.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> Al Jazeera reported on January 3, 2016, that they were in contact with
