Source Confirms HGH Sent To Manning House |website=Deadspin.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Nicki Jhabvala |url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_29338568/al-jazeera-reporter-says-second-source-confirmed-hgh |title=Al-Jazeera reporter says second source confirmed HGH shipments to Ashley Manning |newspaper=[[The Denver Post]] |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> On February 5, 2016, it was confirmed that Ashley Manning did receive shipments from the Guyer Institute, but refused to confirm that the shipments had included HGH.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14718227/peyton-manning-legal-team-looked-al-jazeera-documentary |title=Peyton Manning's legal team looked into Al Jazeera documentary |website=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref>
A comparison was made by some sports writers among the media coverage of Manning's wrongdoings and several prominent black athletes, including [[Carolina Panthers]] quarterback [[Cam Newton]] and [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] quarterback [[Jameis Winston]], whose wrongdoings have received considerable negative media coverage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thebiglead.com/2014/09/18/peyton-manning-1996-tennessee-lawsuit-trainer-bare-butt-mooning/ |title=Peyton Manning is Lucky Social Media Wasn't Around in 1996 When He Allegedly Sat on a Female Trainer's Face |publisher=[[The Big Lead]] |date=2014-09-18 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fanbuzz.rare.us/story/cam-newton-has-never-done-anything-as-bad-as-what-peyton-manning-was-accused-of/ |title=Cam Newton has never done anything as bad as what Peyton Manning was accused of |publisher=Fan Buzz |date=2016-02-04 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> [[Dave Zirin]] for ''[[The Nation]]'' stated that "Manning is a commercial leviathan not only because he has had a storied Hall of Fame career but because he is a white, All-American superstar from a prominent family in a league that is 70 percent black."<ref name="thenation1">{{cite magazine|last=Zirin |first=Dave |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/why-they-pardon-peyton/ |title=Why They Pardon Peyton |magazine=The Nation |date=2016-01-06 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref>
On July 25, 2016, the NFL claimed that it could not find 'credible evidence' that Manning used human growth hormone in violation of its policies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Richardson|first=Bradford|title=NFL rebukes Al Jazeera: 'No credible evidence' Peyton Manning used HGH|accessdate=October 5, 2016|date=July 25, 2016|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/25/nfl-rebukes-al-jazeera-peyton-manning-hgh-report/}}</ref>
===Domestic violence=== According to a database compiled by ''USA Today'' in 2014, 85 of the 713 arrests of NFL players since 2000 were due to [[domestic violence]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martinez|first1=Michael|last2=Riojas|first2=Priscilla|title=NFL's past penalties for domestic violence 'a different story'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/09/us/nfl-players-domestic-violence-accusations/|work=CNN|date=September 11, 2014}}</ref> On September 8, 2014, ''[[TMZ|TMZ Sports]]'' released a video of Baltimore Ravens running back [[Ray Rice]] punching his fiancée and dragging her unconscious body out of an elevator led to a two-game suspension.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ray Rice -- ELEVATOR KNOCKOUT ... Fiancee Takes Crushing Punch (Video)|url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/09/08/ray-rice-elevator-knockout-fiancee-takes-crushing-punch-video/?adid=sidebarwidget-most-commented|publisher=TMZ Sports|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}</ref> Criticism of the league's policy towards domestic violence led the league to adopt six-game bans for violations of its domestic violence policy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Almasy|first1=Steve|last2=Nichols|first2=Rachel|title=NFL toughens domestic violence policy with six-game bans|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/28/us/nfl-domestic-violence/index.html|work=CNN|date=August 28, 2014}}</ref> Additional scrutiny was directed towards players who were convicted of domestic violence but were still allowed to play. Carolina Panthers defensive end [[Greg Hardy]] was accused of assaulting an ex-girlfriend in June 2014. He was disciplined by neither his team nor the NFL and has been allowed to continue playing.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gregory|first1=Sean|title=The Convicted Abuser Who's Still Playing In The NFL|url=https://time.com/3329416/greg-hardy-nfl-domestic-violence/|work=Time|date=September 11, 2014}}</ref> 16 female [[United States Senate|U.S. Senators]] urged the league to adopt a zero tolerance policy towards domestic violence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Arit|first1=John|title=Sixteen Female Senators Pressure NFL to Adopt Zero-Tolerance Domestic Violence Policy|url=http://www.thewire.com/politics/2014/09/sixteen-female-senators-pressure-nfl-to-adopt-zero-tolerance-domestic-violence-policy/380064/|work=The Wire|date=September 11, 2014}}</ref> Shortly after the aforementioned incidents, there were a number of PSAs led by NOMORE.org and over a dozen former and current NFL players that aired during NFL games. The purpose of the PSAs were to promote the NOMORE.org campaign of saying no more to domestic violence and raising awareness about the problems surrounding domestic violence.<ref>"NFL Players Say No More PSAs." NOMORE.org. The NO MORE Project. Web. 5 Feb. 2015. <http://nomore.org/nflplayerspsa/>.</ref>
===Player politics=== The NFL has received polarized opinions related to certain political agendas. For example:
*The NFL denied the [[Dallas Cowboys]] request to honor fallen police officers in wake of the [[2016 shooting of Dallas police officers]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/nfl-denies-cowboys-request-to-wear-helmet-decal-honoring-dallas-police-officers-081116 | work=Foxsports.com | title=NFL denies Cowboys' request to wear helmet decal honoring Dallas police | date=2016-11-16}}</ref> * In 2016, [[San Francisco 49ers]] quarterback [[Colin Kaepernick]] sat during the [[National Anthem]] in protest of police violence, which led to [[U.S. national anthem protests (2016-present)|widespread controversy surrounding the national anthem]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000691077/article/colin-kaepernick-explains-why-he-sat-during-national-anthem | work=NFL.com | title=Colin Kaepernick explains why he sat during national anthem | date=2016-08-27}}</ref> *The NFL initially stated they would fine players for wearing [[September 11 attacks]] tribute cleats, which the NFL ultimately did not do due to backlash.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.sbnation.com/2016/9/13/12888178/nfl-odell-beckham-victor-cruz-pat-mcafee-911-fines-cleats | work=sbnation.com | title=NFL won't fine players who wore 9/11 tribute cleats | date=2016-09-14}}</ref> *As mentioned above, during the 2016, 2017, and 2018 seasons, many NFL players from all 32 NFL teams have protested the national anthem due to police brutality, racial inequality, and other controversies around the nation surrounding politics and authority. Players have been caught on camera kneeling, sitting, staying in the locker rooms, and raising their fists while the national anthem was played before kickoffs of games. This led to dropped ratings throughout the NFL, with most fans and critics calling the protests disrespectful. Many videos on YouTube showed fans showing their anger towards players by burning merchandise such as hats, jersies, pictures, and other things. Though the incidents have died down during the 2018 season, they still continue to happen throughout the league. Aside from the NFL, other sports leagues have joined in the protests, such as high school football. This lead to President Donald Trump lamenting "Get that son of a bitch off of the field right now! He's gone! He's fired! Fired!" This line has been both praised and criticized by fans and media alike, with some agreeing that anyone who kneels should be banned, while others say it is too harsh. Ultimately, in 2018, the NFL introduced a policy revolving around the issue.
===Sexual assault lawsuits=== There have been several cases of high-profile sexual assault lawsuits filed against prominent NFL players. These lawsuits have varied in severity of accusation, settlement and punishment, both in court and from the league.
In 1996, while attending the University of Tennessee, quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] was accused of [[sexual assault]] by trainer Jamie Ann Naughright of pressing his genitals against Naughright's face during a foot examination. Manning claims that he was just pulling a prank by "[[mooning]]" another athlete in the room as Naughright bent over to examine him. Both Naughright and the other athlete deny Manning's story. Naughright settled with the university for $300,000 for its alleged failure in four incidents, and resigned from the school. She had initially made a list of 33 complaints about the school.<ref name="chronicle.augusta.com">{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/1997/08/20/oth_213271.shtml#.Vje0i5RHaK1|title=Trainer's settlement involved more than Manning's mooning|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[Augusta Chronicle]]|date=August 20, 1997}}</ref> Naughright filed a defamation lawsuit against Peyton Manning and three other parties in 2002. Manning allegedly defamed her in a book he wrote with his father and author John Underwood. The lawsuit was settled after the court ruled there was sufficient evidence for it to be heard by a jury. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed due to confidentiality terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/colts/2003-12-25-manning-lawsuit_x.htm|title=USATODAY.com – Peyton Manning defamation lawsuit resolved|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2016/02/14/peyton-manning-lawsuit-sexual-harassment-documents-tennessee|title=Documents reveal more litigation in Manning case|first=Michael|last=McCann|magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=February 14, 2016}}</ref>
In 2009 and 2010, Steelers quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] was accused by two women of sexual assault in separate lawsuits, one in Nevada and the other in the state of Georgia. While the first case was muddled with evidence of the accuser bragging of having consensual sex with Roethlisberger prior to filing suit,<ref name="Antonetti-Post-Gazette">{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09220/989640-66.stm#ixzz0Nq1oEgKL|title=Woman's affidavit supports Roethlisberger's denial of sexual assault|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=August 10, 2009|author=Michael A. Fuoco}}</ref> the second case in Georgia was left open with conflicting accounts of the victim's testimony and that of law enforcement and Roethlisberger.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Walker |first1=Hunter |title=Big Ben's Night Out In "Millyvegas": What The Bartenders Saw |url=https://deadspin.com/5487565/big-bens-night-out-in-millyvegas-what-the-bartenders-saw |website=Deadspin |publisher=Gizmodo Media Group |accessdate=July 18, 2018 |date=March 7, 2010}}</ref><ref name=DAtranscript>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourgeorgiahistory.com/ogh/Baldwin_County_DA_Fred_Bright's_transcript|title=Baldwin County DA Fred Bright's transcript|work=Our Georgia History|accessdate=September 27, 2015}}</ref><ref name=AJC01>{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/qbs-case-in-trouble-493407.html|title=QB's case in trouble from the start: NFL's Roethlisberger benefited from lapses in Milledgeville case|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|author=Christian Boone, Bill Torpy and Bill Rankin|date=April 26, 2010|accessdate=August 15, 2012}}</ref> Though no criminal charges were ultimately brought up in either case against him, Roethlisberger was nonetheless suspended for the first six (later four) games of the {{nfly|2010}} season for violating the [[National Football League player conduct policy|NFL player conduct policy]] and ordered to undergo a league-mandated "professional behavior evaluation" and "must adhere to any counseling or treatment that is recommended by the professional evaluators."<ref name="APBW">{{cite news|url=https://www.salon.com/2010/04/21/fbn_roethlisberger_suspension/ |title=Roethlisberger banned 6 games |last=Wilner |first=Barry |date=April 21, 2010 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=April 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
==Coaching controversies==
===Bounty Bowl=== {{main|Bounty Bowl}} In 1989, [[Cowboys-Eagles rivalry|rivals]] [[Philadelphia Eagles|Philadelphia]] and [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] played two games. Later, it was discovered that Eagles head coach [[Buddy Ryan]] had placed a bounty on Cowboys and former Eagles kicker [[Luis Zendejas]]. Concerns first came around when Ryan was the defensive coordinator for the [[Chicago Bears]], who allegedly pooled money into a bag, and if any of the Bears defensive players injures a player, he would get the bag.<ref>{{cite web|author=Times file photo |url=http://www.nj.com/times-sports/index.ssf/2012/03/saints_bountygate_brings_back.html |title=Saints' "Bountygate" brings back memories of Eagles' "Bounty Bowl" |publisher=NJ.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> Suspicions started in the game when various fights happened between the two teams, with Zendejas going out of the game with a concussion from a hard tackle by linebacker [[Jessie Small]] after a kickoff. After the game, Cowboys coach [[Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)|Jimmy Johnson]] alleged that Ryan had placed a bounty on two players: Zendejas and quarterback [[Troy Aikman]], with injuring Aikman being worth possibly $500. However, Ryan dismissed the claims as "high school Charlie stuff".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2012-03-07/sports/31132527_1_eagles-coach-buddy-ryan-bounty-bowl-luis-zendejas |title=1989 Eagles recall original Bounty Bowl|publisher=Philly.com |date=2012-03-07 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> Zendejas later claimed that when he was with the Eagles, a player had once received at least $100–200 each for hits on a kicker and punter, which was the reason why Johnson made the accusation.
In the teams' second meeting, this time in [[Veterans Stadium]] in Philadelphia, the original game set the tone for the second game, especially with NFL commissioner [[Paul Tagliabue]] at the game. Because the snow at the game has yet to be removed, the Eagles' [[700 Level|notoriously rowdy fans]], with a mixture of beer, the snow, the bounty and the hatred for "[[America's Team]]", threw everything within reach at various targets, like back judge [[Al Jury]], who was knocked to the ground by a barrage of [[snowball]]s; Cowboys punter [[Mike Saxon]], who was targeted in the end zone; and Johnson, who was hit with snowballs, ice, and beer as he was escorted off the field by Philadelphia police. The Eagles won both contests, winning the first game 27-0, and the second 20-10.<ref>{{cite web|author=KevinR38 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zSroPtp4jTI |title=1989 Bounty Bowl II |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-12-19 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
===2007 National Football League videotaping controversy=== {{main|2007 National Football League videotaping controversy}} Dubbed Spygate, in 2007, despite the [[New England Patriots]] going [[2007 New England Patriots season|16-0]] for the first time in league history, the team was still in the midst of a controversy surrounding head coach [[Bill Belichick]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/patriots/2007-09-12-belichick-apology_N.htm |title=Belichick apologizes for 'Videogate' |first=Tom |last=Pedulla |work=USA Today |date=2007-09-12 |accessdate=2008-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22190391/ |title=Jets play innocent, wonder 'What is 'Spygate?' |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[MSNBC.com]] |date=2008-12-10 |accessdate=2008-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080113034635/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22190391/ |archivedate=13 January 2008 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In the early part of the season, the Patriots were caught videotaping the hand signals of a [[New York Jets]] coach from a non-fixed roof covered position, and Belichick was fined a league-high $500,000, and the Patriots were fined $250,000. Additionally, the Patriots lost their first-round pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]] (if they made the playoffs), or their second- and third-round picks (if they missed the playoffs).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3018338 |title=Belichick draws $500,000 fine, but avoids suspension – NFL|publisher=ESPN |date=2007-09-14 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> In a widely criticized move, the league destroyed the tapes.<ref name="ESPN.com">{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3392047 |title=Timeline of events and disclosures during Spygate saga |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2008-05-12 |accessdate=2008-05-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517030557/http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3392047 |archivedate=17 May 2008 |url-status=live }}</ref> However, Belichick and most other coaches were then revealed to have done this in the past until it was stopped by memo from Roger Goodell. Belichick's stance was that the rule does not allow videotaping from a mobile camera and the information then used in the same game. The NFL found that Belichick did not use the tape during the same game, yet penalized him more than any other coach in history.<ref name="Yahoo">{{cite news |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=AvAGEAUu07N_iO6wj7sJQKk5nYcB?slug=ap-goodell-specter&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=Belichick has been taping since 2000, Goodell tells Specter |first=Kellman |last=Laurie |agency=Associated Press |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |date=2008-02-13 |accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> From an unknown source, the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' published an article stating that Belichick had done this practice with the [[St. Louis Rams]] practice before [[Super Bowl XXXVI]], an allegation that Belichick denied. The ''Boston Herald'' later printed a retraction to the story, stating that they had been given "bad information".<ref name="Tomase">{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/football/patriots/view.bg?articleid=1070762&srvc=home&position=0|title=Source: Pats Employee Filmed Rams|first=John|last=Tomase|work=[[Boston Herald]]|date=2008-02-02|accessdate=2008-02-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206045732/http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/football/patriots/view.bg?articleid=1070762&srvc=home&position=0|archivedate=6 February 2008|url-status=live}}</ref> In a statement from [[Mike Martz]], the St. Louis Rams ex-offensive coordinator and coach also recalls that Goodell asked him to write a statement, saying that he was satisfied with the NFL's Spygate investigation and was certain the Patriots had not cheated and asking everyone to move on—like leaders of the Steelers and Eagles had done. A congressional inquiry that would put league officials under oath had to be avoided, Martz recalls Goodell telling him. "If it ever got to an investigation, it would be terrible for the league," Goodell said.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2015/9/8/9275433/espn-patriots-spygate-deflategate-roger-goodell-bill-belichick|title=ESPN just nuked the Patriots and NFL for Spygate|date=8 September 2015|work=SB Nation|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
===2012 New Orleans Saints bounty scandal=== {{main|New Orleans Saints bounty scandal}} In 2012, the [[New Orleans Saints]] were discovered to have run a "slush fund" under former defensive coordinator [[Gregg Williams]], that paid out bonuses, called "bounties", to purposely injure offensive players that the Saints were playing against. The system was known to have operated during Williams's time in [[Buffalo Bills|Buffalo]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Tim Graham |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/bills-nfl/article747663.ece |title=Bills bounty system under Williams alleged – Bills & NFL |work=The Buffalo News |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> and [[Washington Redskins|Washington]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/redskins/washington-redskins-offered-bounties-for-big-hits-under-former-assistant-coach-gregg-williams/2012/03/02/gIQAH0RlnR_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Mark | last=Maske | title=Stats, scores and schedules | date=2012-03-04}}</ref> Rumors started in 2009 during the Saints [[Super Bowl XLIV]] run in the 2009 NFC Championship game against the Vikings, where the Saints defense was allegedly trying to hurt Viking quarterback [[Brett Favre]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Silverman |first=Steve |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ycn-11050204 |title='Bountygate' Details Get Uglier by the Moment – NFL|work=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Seifert |first=Kevin |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/39041/saints-shots-at-brett-favre-were-no-secret |title=Saints' shots at Brett Favre were no secret – NFC North Blog |publisher=ESPN |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> Other than the Vikings, the Saints also allegedly targeted Bears<ref>{{cite web|last=Wright |first=Michael C. |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4675326/bears-wonder-if-saints-targeted-them |title=Bears wonder if Saints targeted them – Chicago Bears Blog – ESPN Chicago |publisher=ESPN |date=2010-01-02 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> and [[Carolina Panthers]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Yasinskas |first=Pat |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcsouth/post/_/id/32684/nfl-saints-targeted-cam-newton |title=NFL: Saints targeted Cam Newton – NFC South Blog|publisher=ESPN |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> players, and the program became even more notorious in the 2011 NFC Divisional Playoff Game against the [[San Francisco 49ers]], when filmmaker [[Sean Pamphilon]] released audio tapes of Williams telling his players to injure a select group of 49ers, one of them being running back [[Kendall Hunter]], and to knock him out, as well as going after [[Kyle Williams (wide receiver)|Kyle Williams]] because of his history of concussions. Williams also told them to injure [[Vernon Davis]]' ankles and [[Anterior cruciate ligament injury|tear]] wide receiver [[Michael Crabtree]]'s [[anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]]. According to Pamphilon, Williams also appeared to put a bounty on quarterback [[Alex Smith]] after he told his men to hit Smith in the chin, "then he rubs his thumb against his index and middle fingers -- the cash sign -- and says, 'I got the first one. I got the first one. Go get it. Go lay that motherfucker out.'"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=Anw9sHdXItbteN7R4ozB1Qg5nYcB?slug=ms-silver_gregg_williams_speech_saints_49ers_bounty_040412|title=Source: Gregg Williams instructed Saints during speech to injure Niners offensive players|last=Silver|first=Michael|work=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=2012-04-05}}</ref>
Ultimately, Goodell handed down one of the harshest penalties in league history, by suspending Williams indefinitely, head coach [[Sean Payton]] for the [[2012 New Orleans Saints season|2012 season]], interim head coach [[Joe Vitt]] for the first six games, and general manager [[Mickey Loomis]] for eight games.<ref name="sanction">{{cite web|title=NFL suspends Saints coach Payton for one year without pay|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d827c0dd9/article/nfl-suspends-saints-coach-payton-for-one-year-without-pay?module=HP11_breaking_news|work=NFL.com}}</ref> Saints linebacker [[Jonathan Vilma]] was also suspended for the season, as well as defensive linemen [[Anthony Hargrove]] and [[Will Smith (American football)|Will Smith]] for eight and four games, respectively. Former Saints and then [[Cleveland Browns]] linebacker [[Scott Fujita]] was also suspended for three games.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/jonathan-vilma-suspended-entire-season-170017552.html |title=Jonathan Vilma: Suspended for Entire Season|work=Yahoo! Sports |date=2012-05-02 |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> The players' suspensions were later thrown out on appeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000059459/article/saints-player-bounty-suspensions-overturned-on-appeal |title=Saints player bounty suspensions overturned on appeal |publisher=NFL.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-22}}</ref>
==Player safety== {{further|Concussions in American football}} There has been widespread controversy over the league's part in player safety. Goodell has fined Lions player [[Ndamukong Suh]] for stomping, as well as Steelers linebacker [[James Harrison (American football)|James Harrison]] for a hard tackle, as well as suspending the 2 players.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/post/james-harrisons-hit-on-colt-mccoy-draws-attention/2011/12/09/gIQAz539hO_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Cindy | last=Boren | title=Stats, scores and schedules | date=2011-12-09}}</ref>
The league has also been criticized for its efforts in preventing concussions, in which eight former players have died, and have also had concussions throughout their careers. In 1994, former commissioner [[Paul Tagliabue]] created the Mild Traumatic Brain Injury Committee in order to study the effects of concussions on players.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espnmag/story?id=3644940|title=Elliot Pellman says it's okay to play in the NFL after suffering a concussion|website=ESPN.com|access-date=2016-04-21}}</ref> With the suicide of linebacker [[Junior Seau]] in 2012, concerns arose about the connection between player deaths and concussions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtop.com/?nid=267&sid=2852304 |title=Seau's death raises questions about kids' concussions |publisher=WTOP.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> As a result, on April 9, 2013, a lawsuit involving 4,100 plaintiffs and 222 consolidated lawsuits against the NFL will be held by a federal court.<ref>{{cite web|last=Breer|first=Albert|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000158376/article/concussion-lawsuit-state-of-things-entering-tuesdays-hearing|title=Concussion lawsuit: State of things entering Tuesday's hearing|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=2013-04-08|accessdate=2013-04-08}}</ref>
In 2005, [[Bennet Omalu]] found evidence of [[Chronic traumatic encephalopathy|CTE]] in the brain of former [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] player [[Mike Webster]]. The NFL initially hounded Omalu and tried to force him to withdraw his findings. Since this discovery, however, 91 other former NFL players have been tested for CTE at the VA-BU-CLF Brain bank at [[Boston University]], with 87 of these tests showing signs of CTE.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://concussionfoundation.org/learning-center/what-is-cte|title=What is CTE?|website=Concussion Legacy Foundation|access-date=2016-04-21}}</ref> The story of Bennet Omalu has since been made into a [[Concussion (2015 film)|major motion picture]].
Also, in recent years, the number of [[Anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] tears and other serious knee injuries has gone up, including in 2013 an increase of 64 percent from 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-12-09/gronkowski-spotlights-nfl-s-60-surge-in-knee-injuries-from-2011|title=Rob Gronkowski's Knee Injury Spotlights NFL's Surge in ACL Tears|date=10 December 2013|publisher=|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/95723/inside-slant-big-spike-in-acl-injuries|title=Inside Slant: Big spike in ACL injuries|work=go.com}}</ref>
==Washington Redskins team name== {{main|Washington Redskins name controversy}} The [[Washington Redskins]] have been subject to [[Native American mascot controversy|dispute]] with some in the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] community for many years claiming the term "[[redskin]]" to be derogatory towards Native Americans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2009/11/the-washington-redskins-controversy-an-interview-with-amanda-blackhorse/ |title=The Washington Redskins Controversy: An Interview with Amanda Blackhorse « Above the Law: A Legal Web Site – News, Commentary, and Opinions on Law Firms, Lawyers, Law School, Law Suits, Judges and Courts |publisher=Abovethelaw.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
==Free agency== The league's [[free agent|free agency]] system originally used a system that was adopted from [[Major League Baseball]], where a player stays with a team until his contract expires, then can negotiate with the team to stay. In 1947, the league adopted the 1-year system, where a team can only renew a player's contract for one year. In 1963, the "[[Pete Rozelle|Rozelle]] Rule" was created, where a team that signs a player must compensate for the player's expenses from his previous team. If a team refuses, commissioner Rozelle decided the compensation. The players union found this system to be unfair, and eventually won a court action in 1976. However, the league's [[collective bargaining agreement]] still kept the compensation rule, but removed Rozelle's authority. Ultimately, in {{NFL Year|1987}}, the players union went on strike. Two years later, the union sued again, but was prohibited from suing the league for [[antitrust laws|anti-trust]]. From 1989 to 1992, instead of the current free agent system, the league used a system to acquire and release players called [[Plan B free agency]]. The system consisted of teams protecting 37 players, and having the remaining players becoming unrestricted free agents. The players eventually decertified the union, leading to players filing individual lawsuits.<ref name=BleacherReport>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/18183-nfl-history-the-road-to-free-agency |title=NFL History: The Road to Free Agency |website=Bleacher Report |date=2008-04-17 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> However, eight players sued the league for violating their antitrust laws, and calling the system an unfair trade restraint. The system ultimately was deemed illegal by the jury, and was ended in 1992.<ref>Freeman, Mike. "[http://tech.mit.edu/V112/N39/nfl.39w.html NFL Is in Violation of Antitrust Laws, Jury Decides]", ''The Tech Online Edition'', 11 September 1992. Retrieved on 2008-05-01.</ref><ref>George, Thomas. "[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE5D81E38F932A2575AC0A964958260 FOOTBALL; N.F.L.'s Free-Agency System Is Found Unfair by U.S. Jury]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 11, 1992. Retrieved on 2008-05-01.</ref> The lawsuit eventually led to the establishment of the current system, which involves the use of a salary cap.<ref name=BleacherReport />
===2011 lockout=== {{main|2011 NFL lockout}} However, in 2011, the league and the [[National Football League Players Association]] eventually failed to arrive at a consensus for the [[National Football League collective bargaining agreement|collective bargaining agreement (CBA)]], and eventually led to the lockout on March 12.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wivb.com/dpp/sports/bills_and_nfl/other_nfl/nfl-lockout-begins |title=NFL Lockout Begins |publisher=WIVB.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> The lockout threatened to cancel games,<ref>{{cite news|author=Alex Brandon/The Times-Picayune |url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2011/04/if_nfl_lockout_lingers_games_i.html |title=If NFL lockout lingers, games in Week 2 and Week 4 could potentially be cancelled – New Orleans Saints Football NFL News |newspaper=NOLA.com |date=2011-04-23 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> even though only the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame Game]] was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-07-22/sports/ct-spt-0722-olivet-bears-chicago--20110722_1_bears-and-rams-training-camp-free-agents |title=NFL lockout: Hall of Fame Game exhibition canceled; Chicago Bears could report to training camp Wednesday if NFL players ratify deal|work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=2011-07-22 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> The lockout eventually ended on July 21 with a new CBA.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schefter|first=Adam |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/6797238/2011-nfl-lockout-owners-players-come-deal-all-points-sources-say |title=2011 NFL lockout – Owners, players come to deal on all points, sources say|publisher=ESPN |date=2011-07-25 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/nfl-and-nflpa-agree-to-terms-of-new-collective-bargaining-agreement-072511 |title=Sources: NFL, NFLPA agree to terms of new CBA – NFL News | FOX Sports on MSN |publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|FOX Sports]] |date=2011-07-25 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref>
==Referee labor dispute== {{main|2012 NFL referee lockout}} In {{NFL Year|2012}}, the league and the NFL Referees Association became involved in a dispute over the collective bargaining agreement between the two parties. Eventually, the league then locked out the officials in June, and turned to replacement officials to officiate the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/8314433/nfl-use-replacement-officials-start-regular-season |title=NFL to use replacement officials for start of regular season – ESPN Chicago |publisher=ESPN |date=2012-08-30 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> A month later, the association filed a complaint to the [[National Labor Relations Board]] against the league for unfair labor practices.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/football/nfl/06/21/nfl-referees-unfair-labor.ap/index.html#ixzz212R1eXRa |title=NFL Referees Association files unfair labor practice charge against league – NFL|work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date= 2012-06-21|accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> The replacement referees were met with criticism from fans, players<ref>{{cite web | url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/45289/robbie-gould-replacement-officials-clueless | title=Robbie Gould: Replacement refs 'clueless' | publisher=ESPN | date=August 24, 2012 | accessdate=August 27, 2012}}</ref> and coaches.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/belichick-fined-50k-shanahan-25k-174534755--nfl.html |title=Belichick fined 50K, Kyle Shanahan 25K by NFL|work=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> Incidents included the week one [[Seattle Seahawks]]–[[Arizona Cardinals]] game, where the Seahawks were given an extra timeout,<ref>{{cite news|last=Farrar |first=Doug |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/replacement-refs-seahawks-extra-timeout-cardinals-win-anyway-004714666--nfl.html |title=Replacement refs give Seahawks an extra timeout, Cardinals win anyway | Shutdown Corner – Yahoo! Sports |work=Yahoo! Sports |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> week two where side judge Brian Stropolo was removed from the [[New Orleans Saints]]–[[Carolina Panthers]] game for being a Saints fan,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/16/brian-stropolo-saints-fan-nfl-official-side-judge_n_1888202.html |title=Brian Stropolo, NFL Replacement Official, Removed For Being Saints Fan |work=[[Huffington Post]] |date= 2012-09-16|accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> and the [[2012 Packers–Seahawks officiating controversy|controversial ending]] to the [[Green Bay Packers]]-Seahawks game in week three. In late September, [[ESPN]] analyst [[Chris Mortensen]] announced that the two groups reached an agreement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/8427652/locked-nfl-referees-return-early-week-sources |title=Locked-out NFL referees could return as early as this week – sources|publisher=ESPN |date=2008-01-01 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref>
==Expansion draft== Originally, the NFL did not have an [[expansion draft]], and instead, expansion teams were given whatever players were available; the rules at the time gave these teams two players from each existing franchise and the remainder from the local area to make up a 55-player roster. When the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] were added to the NFL in 1976, their roster ended up being composed mostly of aging veterans and inexperienced rookies, and as a result, Tampa Bay had the first winless season in modern NFL history en route to losing their first 26 games (the longest losing streak in NFL history). After significant public criticism, the NFL created an expansion draft to avoid a repeat of this very poor start for future expansion teams.
==Controversial calls== {{See also|List of NFL nicknames#Rules named after NFL figures|label 1=Rules named after NFL figures}}
The league has been criticized for various calls that would later be disputed, and would also lead to a segment on [[NFL Top 10]] called ''Top Ten Most Controversial Calls''.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-network-total-access/09000d5d8187af4c/Top-10-controversial-calls |title=NFL Videos: Top 10 controversial calls |publisher=NFL.com |date=2010-06-03 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> Some of these controversial calls have directly led to rule changes.
===Immaculate Reception=== {{main|Immaculate Reception}} In the [[1972–73 NFL playoffs#AFC: Pittsburgh Steelers 13, Oakland Raiders 7|1972 AFC Wild Card Game]], the Steelers and Raiders fought to a 7-6 lead for Oakland. With 22 seconds left in the game, Steelers quarterback [[Terry Bradshaw]] heaved a pass towards [[John Fuqua]], and Raiders safety [[Jack Tatum]] collided with Fuqua at the same time as the ball's arrival. Tatum's hit knocked Fuqua down and the ball flying backwards. Steelers running back [[Franco Harris]], who had been heading downfield in the event that Bradshaw needed another receiver, caught the ball before it hit the ground and ran for the game-winning touchdown. However, fans and critics eventually asked the question: Whom did the ball touch in the Tatum/Fuqua collision? If it hit only Fuqua, the pass would've been illegal under the rules at the time, and Oakland would have won; if it hit Tatum, or both Fuqua and Tatum (in any order), it would have been legal. The rule stated that once an offensive player touches a pass, he is the only offensive player that can catch the pass. However, if a defensive player touches the pass "first, or simultaneously with or subsequent to its having been touched by only one [offensive] player, then all [offensive] players become and remain eligible" to catch the pass.<ref>Official Rules for Professional Football 1971, The National Football League, Rule 7, Section 5, Article 2, Item 1, p.44.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steelersfever.com/immaculate_reception.html |title=Immaculate Reception |publisher=Steelers Fever |date=1972-12-23 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===Holy Roller=== {{main|Holy Roller (American football)}} In 1978, the [[Oakland Raiders]] were trailing the [[San Diego Chargers]] 20-14 with 10 seconds left in the game. Raiders quarterback [[Ken Stabler]] took the snap, and saw Chargers linebacker [[Woodrow Lowe]] about to sack him. Stabler eventually deliberately fumbled the ball towards San Diego's goal line, where running back [[Pete Banaszak]] attempted to recover, but lost his footing and sent the ball closer to the end zone. Tight end [[Dave Casper]] attempted to pick it up, but was unable to, and kicked the ball into the end zone, where he recovered it for the game-tying touchdown.<ref>{{cite web|last=Media |first=Raiders |url=http://www.raiders.com/news/article-1/The-Holy-Roller/18355482-ad78-43cd-9bf8-da77e709fecf |title=The Holy Roller |publisher=Raiders.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> This later led to disputes over whether or not Banaszak and Casper intentionally batted the ball forward, which would be a penalty, as well as whether or not Stabler fumbled the ball or threw a forward pass. The play was eventually ruled as legal. The Raiders would then make the extra point to win 21-20.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/release.aspx?release_id=1737 |title=History Release » The "Holy Roller" |publisher=[[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] |date=1978-09-10 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> In the ensuing off-season, the league enacted the so-called "Ken Stabler Rule": on fourth down at any time in the game or any down in the final two minutes of a half, if a player fumbles forward, only the fumbling player can recover and/or advance the ball. If that player's teammate recovers the ball, it is placed back at the spot of the fumble.<ref name="rulesname"> {{cite web | url=http://www.footballresearch.com/articles/frpage.cfm?topic=rulesname | title=Rules of the Name, or How The Emmitt Rule Became the Emmitt Rule | publisher=Professional Football Researchers Association, Mirrored at the Internet Archive | accessdate=2009-03-31 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211145916/http://www.footballresearch.com/articles/frpage.cfm?topic=rulesname | archivedate=2007-12-11 | url-status=dead }}</ref>
===1979 AFC Championship=== {{main|1979–80 NFL playoffs#AFC Championship: Pittsburgh Steelers 27, Houston Oilers 13}} Against the Steelers in the [[1979–80 NFL playoffs#AFC Championship: Pittsburgh Steelers 27, Houston Oilers 13|1979 AFC Championship Game]], the [[Houston Oilers]] fell behind 17-10 late in the third quarter. Oilers quarterback [[Dan Pastorini]] then threw a pass to [[Mike Renfro]], who caught the ball in the back of the end zone. However, though television networks proved that Renfro was inbounds, instant replay was not in use at the time, and the referees ultimately ruled Renfro out of bounds. The Steelers would then score another touchdown and go to [[Super Bowl XIV]].<ref name=PageTwo /> The league would not institute instant replay until 1986.
===Music City Miracle=== {{main|Music City Miracle}} The Titans and [[Buffalo Bills]] squared off in the [[1999–2000 NFL playoffs#AFC: Tennessee Titans 22, Buffalo Bills 16|1999 AFC Wild Card Game]], and the Bills led 16-15 with 16 seconds left in the game. After Bills kicker [[Steve Christie]] kicked off to Titans returner [[Lorenzo Neal]], Neal handed the ball to [[Frank Wycheck]], who then threw a lateral across the field to [[Kevin Dyson]], who then ran 75 yards for a touchdown and the lead. This then led to officials debating over whether or not Wycheck's pass was a forward pass or a lateral. Referee [[Phil Luckett]] then deemed the pass a lateral, giving Tennessee the win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/music-city-miracle |title=Music City Miracle — History.com This Day in History — 1/8/2000 |publisher=History.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===Bert Emanuel=== {{main|1999–2000 NFL playoffs#NFC Championship: St. Louis Rams 11, Tampa Bay Buccaneers 6}} In the [[1999–2000 NFL playoffs#NFC Championship: St. Louis Rams 11, Tampa Bay Buccaneers 6|1999 NFC Championship Game]], the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] trailed the [[St. Louis Rams]] by 5 points. With 47 seconds left in the game, Buccaneers quarterback [[Shaun King (American football)|Shaun King]] threw an 11-yard pass to [[Bert Emanuel]], who caught the ball, but had the play overturned after the ball touched the ground, giving the Rams the trip to [[Super Bowl XXXIV]].<ref name=PageTwo>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/worstcalls/010730.html |title=ESPN.com – Page2 – The List: Worst calls in sports history |publisher=ESPN |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=BILL PENNINGTON|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/24/sports/pro-football-bucs-grounded-by-a-replay-call-voiding-a-catch.html |title=PRO FOOTBALL; Bucs Grounded By a Replay Call Voiding a Catch|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2000-01-24 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> The league then enacted the "Bert Emanuel Rule" after the season: the ball can touch the ground during a completed pass as long as the receiver maintains control of the ball.'<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.buccaneers.com/news/newsdetail.aspx?newsid=4980 | title=Buccaneers.com – The Answer Man, Series 3, Vol. 7 | date=2006-01-16 | accessdate=2006-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.outsidethebeltway.com/2008/05/nfl-rules-named-after-players/ |title=NFL Rules Named After Players » OTB Sports |publisher=Sports.outsidethebeltway.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===Bottlegate=== {{main|Bottlegate}} In a regular season game between the [[2001 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] and [[2001 Jacksonville Jaguars season|Jacksonville Jaguars]], the Browns were driving down the field for a potential game-winning touchdown in order to keep their playoff hopes alive. After Browns quarterback [[Tim Couch]] passed to receiver [[Quincy Morgan]] to convert a crucial fourth down, the catch appeared to be bobbled but the referees initially ruled a completion. Couch then spiked the ball with 48 seconds remaining, but the referees subsequently reviewed the previous play and overturned it, despite a rule that stipulated that a play cannot be reviewed after another play has been completed. The controversial decision, which effectively sealed the outcome of the game and eliminated the Browns from the playoffs, angered Browns fans, who started tossing plastic beer bottles onto the field and forced the refs to declare the game over until the league office called and ordered the final 48 seconds, which consisted of two kneeldowns by the Jaguars, to be played.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cleveland.com/browns/2014/12/bottlegate_oral_history_cleveland_browns.html |title=An oral history of BottleGate, 13 years after Cleveland Browns fans stole the spotlight |last=Meisel |first=Zack |date=2014-12-16 |website=cleveland.com |language=en-US |access-date=2019-04-28}}</ref>
===Tuck Rule=== {{main|Tuck Rule Game}} During a 2001 AFC playoff game between the [[New England Patriots]] and [[Oakland Raiders]], the Raiders forced a fumble near the end of the game. The Raiders recovered the fumble, thereby securing their victory. However, the call went into review by the booth, and upon review it was determined to be an incomplete pass due to the [[Tuck rule (American football)|tuck rule]] being applied. Under the rule, if a passer "is holding the ball to pass it forward, any intentional forward movement of his arm starts a forward pass, even if the player loses possession of the ball as he is attempting to tuck it back toward his body."<ref name="wparticle_tuck">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/14/AR2005101401828.html|title=Tuck Rule Hard to Grasp|accessdate=2012-01-14 | work=The Washington Post | first=Mark | last=Maske | date=October 15, 2005}}</ref> The Patriots went on to win the game and ultimately the Super Bowl. Fans and experts alike have disputed whether the call was correct, and whether the rule should even exist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2011/01/11/mike-pereira-time-to-change-the-tuck-rule/ |title=Mike Pereira: Time to change the tuck rule | ProFootballTalk |publisher=ProFootballTalk.NBCSports.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref>
===2002 NFC Wild Card Game=== {{main|2002–03 NFL playoffs#NFC: San Francisco 49ers 39, New York Giants 38}} During the NFC wild card game between the [[San Francisco 49ers]] and [[New York Giants]], the Giants created a first half lead, which the 49ers overcame by scoring 25 points. Late in the game, the Giants, down by one point, attempted to kick the game-winning field goal with six seconds left. However, long snapper [[Trey Junkin]] botched the snap, leading to holder [[Matt Allen]] to throw a desperation pass to [[Rich Seubert]], which fell incomplete, giving San Francisco the win. During the play, a penalty was called, but on New York for having an illegal man downfield. However, Seubert actually did report, but a different Giants player was actually illegally downfield. The 49ers would also have been penalized for pass interference on defensive end [[Chike Okeafor]] for pulling down Seubert, which wasn't called.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weisman |first=Larry |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2003-01-06-giants-49ers-officials_x.htm |title=NFL: Officials missed pass interference call in Giants-49ers |work=USA Today |date=2003-01-07 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===Super Bowl XL=== {{main|Super Bowl XL#Reaction to officiating}} In [[Super Bowl XL]], the [[Seattle Seahawks]] were denied a touchdown when officials called penalized Seahawks receiver [[Darrell Jackson]] for "pushing off" against [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] safety [[Chris Hope]] during Jackson's touchdown reception in the first quarter. In the second quarter, Steelers quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] scored on a quarterback sneak, and Seattle challenged the call, claiming that Roethlisberger did not break the plane of the end zone, but the play was confirmed after a review. In the fourth quarter, Seahawks tackle [[Sean Locklear]] was penalized for holding Steelers linebacker [[Clark Haggans]] during a long pass. Seahawks quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] was also penalized for allegedly making an illegal block during [[Ike Taylor]]'s interception return.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burke |first=Brian |url=http://www.advancednflstats.com/2010/08/how-much-did-super-bowl-xls-officiating.html |title=How Much Did Super Bowl XL's Officiating Affect The Outcome? |publisher=Advanced NFL Stats |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> The Steelers would go on to win 21-10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/superbowl/history/recap/sbxl |title=Super Bowl XL Game Recap |publisher=NFL.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref> Four years later, referee [[Bill Leavy]] issued an apology to the Seahawks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2010/08/06/four-years-later-bill-leavy-apologizes-to-seahawks/ |title=Four years later, Bill Leavy apologizes to Seahawks | ProFootballTalk |publisher=ProFootballTalk.NBCSports.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===2012 Packers–Seahawks game=== {{main|Fail Mary}} On September 24, 2012, the [[Green Bay Packers]] faced the [[Seattle Seahawks]] on Monday Night Football. With the NFL and the league's regular referees [[2012 NFL referee lockout|locked in a contract dispute]], replacement officials were acquired to call the games for the first 3–4 weeks. As in previous games, there were many questionable calls made by the replacement officials during the game. In the 4th quarter, with only 8 seconds left in the game, the Packers were winning 12-7, with the Seahawks inside the 30-yard line, with one last play to decide the game. Seahawks quarterback [[Russell Wilson]] threw a [[Hail Mary pass]] to the end zone. The pass ended up being caught by both Seahawks receiver [[Golden Tate]] and Packers defensive back [[M. D. Jennings]]. The two officials standing near the play each made their own call of the play. One official seemed to raise his arms to signal a Packers interception, while the other official raised his arms to signal a Seahawks touchdown. As with new NFL rules on instant replay, all touchdowns were liable to official review. The play was reviewed, while the Seahawks crowded the field in celebration. After a few minutes, full of controversy, the officials declared the play's ruling stood as a Seahawks touchdown, giving Seattle a 13-12 lead with the extra point pending.<ref>{{cite web|title=NFL: Seahawks' victory stands|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/8423928/nfl-statement-says-refs-made-right-call-end-game-green-bay-packers-seattle-seahawks|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref>
Almost instantly, controversy reigned as replays showed that before the catch, Tate pushed off Packers defender [[Sam Shields]], but the officials missed an offensive pass interference penalty call on Tate that would have disallowed the score and ensured a Packers victory. As pass interference is not reviewable, the replay officials (who were not replacements) could only review the simultaneous catch ruling. After they upheld the simultaneous possession as a completion in favor of the Seahawks, the controversy surrounding the play led to a plausible disdain from not only irate Packer fans but also NFL fans in general. It was reported that in the hours after the game, the NFL commissioner's office received over 70,000 voice-mails regarding the play. The controversy even drew remarks from people outside of football, as basketball player [[LeBron James]] and professional golfer [[Bubba Watson]] both sent messages via Twitter giving their own criticism on the play.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wallace |first=Kamal |url=http://www.hlntv.com/article/2012/09/25/referees-nfl-seattle-seahawks-green-bay-packers |title=Twitter erupts over NFL replacement refs' call |publisher=[[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]] |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> [[NASCAR]] driver [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] stated that the season has been "stained in a way that's irreparable".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2012/09/25/dale-earnhardt-jr-nfl-referees/70001129/1#.UGN6yFJu_qM |title=Junior: NFL season 'stained in way that's irreparable' |work=USA Today |date=2011-11-28 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref>
===2018 NFC Championship=== {{main|2018 NFC Championship Game}} The 2018 NFC Championship between the [[Los Angeles Rams]] and [[New Orleans Saints]] involved a controversial call in which Rams defender [[Nickell Robey-Coleman]] collided with [[Tommylee Lewis]] of the Saints on a pass from [[Drew Brees]] late in the game. Robey-Coleman was not flagged on the play, but several commentators and Saints fans complained that one should've been thrown for [[pass interference]] on Robey-Coleman. Had the penalty been thrown, the Saints would've been given a fresh set of downs and would've been able to run the clock down to the final seconds to be in position to kick the game-winning field goal. Instead, the Saints kicked the field goal from there to go ahead 23–20 with a little under two minutes to go. The Rams kicked a field goal to tie the game in regulation time and send it into overtime, where they would win 26–23 on another field goal following a Brees interception. After the game, the NFL came under fire for its rule surrounding pass interference penalties, with some commentators calling the no-call among the worst in league history.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} The day after the game, an online petition was filed by Saints fans to convince the NFL to replay the final couple of minutes because of the incident. Another day later, the Saints filed a lawsuit against the NFL due to the call. Many outlets dubbed the call the worst of the 2018 season and amongst the worst in football history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theringer.com/nfl/2019/1/20/18190982/saints-rams-nfc-championship-game-missed-pass-interference-nickell-robey-coleman-tommylee-lewis|title=Ball Does Lie: The Saints Just Lost on the Worst Missed Call in NFL Playoff History|last=Heifetz|first=Danny|date=2019-01-20|website=The Ringer|access-date=2019-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.profootballweekly.com/2019/01/21/missed-pi-might-have-been-worst-non-call-ever-but-will-nfl-change-replay-because-of-it/apmrsag/|title=Missed PI might have been worst non-call ever, but will NFL change replay because of it?|last=Edholm|first=Eric|website=www.profootballweekly.com|access-date=2019-03-08}}</ref> All arguments about the call fell on deaf ears, and the Rams went on to the Super Bowl, where they lost 13-3 to the New England Patriots. In 2019, the NFL made pass interference calls challengeable for head coaches.
==Deflategate== {{Main|Deflategate}} On January 18, 2015, the [[New England Patriots]] defeated the [[Indianapolis Colts]] 45-7 in the [[AFC Championship Game]]. Prior to and during the game, the Colts accused the Patriots of underinflating their footballs. Following a five-month investigation, the NFL announced on May 11, 2015 that quarterback [[Tom Brady]] would be suspended without pay for four games of the [[2015 NFL season|upcoming NFL season]] for more probably than not being generally aware that someone possibly deflated some of the balls after the referee tested them. The rules at the time called for a warning to be issued and a possible fine for this infraction. If a player continued, after being warned, to break this rule during the game, the player was to be thrown out of the game. The Patriots were also fined $1 million and forfeited their first round selection in the [[2016 NFL draft]] and their fourth round selection in the 2017 NFL draft.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Gregg|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000492185/article/brady-suspended-4-games-patriots-forfeit-2016-first-rounder|title=Patriots' Tom Brady suspended 4 games|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=May 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name="National Football League">{{cite web|title= NFL releases statement on Patriots' violations|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000492190/article/nfl-releases-statement-on-patriots-violations|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref>
On May 14, 2015, the [[National Football League Players Association]] (NFLPA) filed an appeal of Brady's four-game suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/12887452/nflpa-appeals-four-game-suspension-new-england-patriots-quarterback-tom-brady|title=NFLPA appeals Patriots QB Tom Brady's four-game suspension|publisher=ESPN.com|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
On July 28, 2015, the NFL announced the upholding of Brady's four-game suspension.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Gregg|title=Roger Goodell upholds Tom Brady suspension|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000504258/article/roger-goodell-upholds-tom-brady-suspension|publisher=National Football League|date=July 28, 2015|accessdate=July 28, 2015}}</ref>
After NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] upheld the suspension in an internal appeal, a federal court case on the matter was started. On September 3, 2015, Judge [[Richard M. Berman]] ruled to vacate Goodell's four game suspension of Brady, due to absence of "...the requisites of fairness and due process."<ref name="JudgeNullifiesBradySuspension">{{cite web|last=Orr|first=Conor|title=Judge nullifies Tom Brady's four-game suspension|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000520618/article/judge-nullifies-tom-bradys-fourgame-suspension|publisher=National Football League|date=September 3, 2015|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref> On April 25, 2016, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] overturned Judge Berman's decision to vacate Brady's suspension by a 2-1 majority.<ref name="BermanOverturned">{{cite web|last=Belson|first=Ken|title=N.F.L. Wins Appeal, and Tom Brady Has Little Recourse|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/26/sports/tom-brady-deflategate-new-england-patriots-suspension-reinstated.html|date=April 25, 2016|accessdate=October 5, 2016}}</ref> After the [[en banc]] petition was rejected,<ref name="EnBancRejected">{{cite web|last=Brinson|first=Will|title=Tom Brady's request for rehearing denied, only option left is Supreme Court |date=July 13, 2016|accessdate=October 5, 2016|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/tom-bradys-request-for-rehearing-denied-only-option-left-is-supreme-court/}}</ref> Brady announced he will not pursue further appeals.<ref name="NoFurtherAppeals">{{cite web|last=Cluff|first=Jeremy|title=Patriots' Tom Brady won't appeal further, out for Cardinals game|accessdate=October 5, 2016|date=July 15, 2016|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/sports/heat-index/2016/07/15/patriots-tom-brady-wont-appeal-supreme-court/87135192/}}</ref>
==National Football League on television== The NFL's status as a prime offering by the networks has led some to conclude that unbiased coverage of the league is not possible, although this may be true of most sports. However, with the current [[concentration of media ownership]] in the U.S., the league essentially has broadcast contracts with four media companies ([[CBS Corporation]], [[NBCUniversal]], Fox's parent company [[Fox Corporation]], and ESPN's parent company [[The Walt Disney Company]]) that own a combined vast majority of the American broadcast and cable networks.
===ESPN=== In 2011, ESPN agreed to a deal with the NFL worth more than $15 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/09/sports/football/espn-extends-deal-with-nfl-for-15-billion.html|title=ESPN Extends Deal With N.F.L. for $15.2 Billion|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|date=8 September 2011|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> This fact led several media organizations, including ''[[Forbes]]'', to argue whether the financial relationship with the league creates a conflict of interest when ESPN covers the NFL.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maurybrown/2015/08/25/espns-uncomfortable-unnerving-relationship-with-the-nfl/#5b6225251ff2|title=ESPN's Uncomfortable, Unnerving Relationship With The NFL|first=Maury|last=Brown|work=forbes.com}}</ref>
For example, ESPN attempted to run a dramatic series showing steamier aspects of pro football, ''[[Playmakers]]'', but canceled the series after the league reportedly threatened to exclude the network from the next set of TV contracts. The network also withdrew its partnership with the [[PBS]] series ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' on the 2013 documentary "[[League of Denial]]", which chronicles the history of head injuries in the NFL, shortly after a meeting between ESPN executives and league commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] took place in New York City, though ESPN denies pressure from the NFL led to its backing out of the project, claiming a lack of editorial control instead.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/24/sports/football/nfl-pressure-said-to-prompt-espn-to-quit-film-project.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1& |title=N.F.L. Pressure Said to Lead ESPN to Quit Film Project |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/league-of-denial/a-note-from-frontline-espn-and-league-of-denial/|title=A Note from FRONTLINE: ESPN and "League of Denial"|work=pbs.org}}</ref>
Then in July 2015, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that sources within ESPN believed that the NFL gave them a "terrible" 2015 ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' schedule as "payback" for remarks made on air by both ESPN commentators [[Keith Olbermann]] and [[Bill Simmons]] that were critical of the league and Goodell;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/espn-wants-keith-olbermann-quit-806220 |title=ESPN Wants Keith Olbermann to Quit Doing "Commentary" |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=2015-07-01| accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> ESPN parted ways with both Olbermann and Simmons during that same year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2015/07/09/did-the-nfl-punish-espn-with-bad-monday-night-football-games/ |title=Did the NFL punish ESPN with bad 'Monday Night Football' games? |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2015-07-09| accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
===2016 NFL ratings===
The NFL has been a long-standing powerhouse in the television and advertising marketplace, but since about the beginning of the 2016 season, the NFL's ratings have begun to drop. Speculation about the unexpected rating drops covers a myriad of possibilities,<ref>{{cite web|title=NFL memo cites multiple reasons for TV ratings drop in 2016|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/17738537/nfl-memo-cites-multiple-reasons-tv-ratings-drop-2016|website=ESPN|accessdate=9 October 2016}}</ref> including: * the above-mentioned problems with concussions and off-field player conduct (the latter being a problem that has also plagued the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) *reduced feelings of authentic competition due to rapidly-increasing number of penalties called per game<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.revengeofthebirds.com/2016/10/31/13475556/the-nfl-has-a-penalty-problem-penalty-flags-have-made-the-game-nearly-unwatchable|title=The NFL Has a Penalty Problem: Penalty flags have made the game... Nearly Unwatchable|work=Revenge of the Birds|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref><ref name="Beaton">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nfls-penalty-problem-1536839971|title=The NFL's Penalty Surge|last=Beaton|first=Andrew|date=2018-09-13|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/the-nfl-isnt-ready-for-how-big-of-a-disaster-this-season-will-be|title=The NFL Isn't Ready for How Big of a Disaster This Season Will Be|last=Magary|first=Drew|date=2018-08-02|work=GQ|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/photo/2016/10/20/nfl-television-ratings-decline-causes|title=Ranking the reasons why the NFL's ratings are down|work=SI.com|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref> * perceived lackluster matchups * the above-mentioned problems with politics. The 2016 US Presidential elections were a particular sore point with fans, with some of [[Super Bowl LI]]'s commercials in particular having drawn backlash.<ref>{{cite web|last=Godoy|first=Maria|title=Budweiser's Super Bowl Ad And The Great Debate Over What It Means To Be An American|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/03/513263766/budweiser-s-super-bowl-ad-misses-the-real-timelier-story-about-immigrants-and-be|publisher=NPR|accessdate= February 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Framke|first1=Caroline|title=The story behind 84 Lumber's Super Bowl ad about Trump's border wall|url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2017/2/5/14518244/84-lumber-super-bowl-commercial|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Vox|date=February 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Shields|first1=Mike|title=84 Lumber Super Bowl Campaign Shows Border Wall With a Big Door|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/84-lumber-super-bowl-campaign-shows-border-wall-with-a-big-door-1486343484|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Wall Street Journal|date=February 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Payne|first1=Marissa|title=84 Lumber forced to re-tool Super Bowl ad rejected for depicting Trump's border wall|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/tv/ct-84-lumber-super-bowl-ad-trump-wall-20170205-story.html|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|date=February 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Lara|title=The 84 Lumber Super Bowl ad's creative director explains the thinking behind the Mexican immigration-themed spot|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/84-lumber-super-bowl-ad-explained-2017-2|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Business Insider|date=February 5, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The loss in viewership is potentially worrisome for the larger networks that are spending roughly $5 billion for football rights through the 2021 season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ratings Fumble for NFL Surprises Networks, Advertisers|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ratings-fumble-for-nfl-surprises-networks-advertisers-1475764108|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=October 9, 2016}}</ref>
Some news agencies are suggesting the decline in viewership is about the recent protest by some players of the US anthem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Confirmed: NFL Losing Millions Of TV Viewers Because Of National Anthem Protests|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2016/10/05/confirmed-nfl-losing-millions-of-tv-viewers-because-of-national-anthem-protests/#2155b38574b7|website=Forbes|accessdate=October 9, 2016}}</ref> The NFL addressed this concern in a memo leaked on Twitter to the NFL organizations "that we see no evidence that concern over player protests during the National Anthem is having any material impact on our ratings."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/darrenrovell/status/784428496089182208|accessdate=October 9, 2016}}{{better source|date=February 2017}}</ref>
=== Increased Penalties and Ratings === The NFL has seen a vast increase in penalties called per game and total penalty yards per game. From 2009 to 2016 penalties per game increased by 20 percent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://247sports.com/nfl/dallas-cowboys/Bolt/NFLs-penalty-count-up-more-than-20-percent-since-2009-48360555/|title=NFL's penalty count up more than 20 percent since 2009|work=Dallas Cowboys|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Through week 1 of the 2018 regular season, penalties are up another 19 percent vs 2017.<ref name="Beaton"/> Week one of the 2018 NFL season saw the second-most accepted penalties called of any single week in the past 10 years with 255 called, an increase of 35% per game from the previous season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.behindthesteelcurtain.com/2018/9/12/17842576/week-1-of-2018-set-a-new-nfl-record-for-penalties-in-a-week-steelers-browns-al-riveron-news|title=Week 1 of 2018 set a new NFL record for penalties in a week|work=Behind the Steel Curtain|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref> Complaints about increased changes in the rulebook making the rules too convoluted to understand and reducing the perceived quality of competition have colored the media surrounding the 2018 NFL season particularly.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/06/sports/nfl-week-1-tackling-rule.html|title=The N.F.L. Struggles to Tackle Its Latest Problem: Tackling|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/10/08/nfls-penalty-problem-reaches-a-new-height-each-week/|title=NFL's penalty problem reaches a new height each week|date=2018-10-08|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en-US}}</ref>

The '''[[National Football League]] Competition Committee''' was created in 1968 following the announcement of the [[AFL-NFL merger]]. It replaced the NFL Rules Committee, which was formed in 1932 when the NFL adopted its own rulebook. Prior to 1932 the NFL used the college rulebook.
Members of the Competition Committee are chosen by the [[NFL commissioner]]. The members are:<ref>{{cite web|title=The NFL Competition Committee|url=http://operations.nfl.com/football-ops/league-governance/the-nfl-competition-committee/|website=NFL.com|accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
*[[Rich McKay]] (chairman) – president, [[Atlanta Falcons]] *[[John Mara]] – owner, [[New York Giants]] *[[Stephen Jones (Dallas Cowboys)|Stephen Jones]] – owner, [[Dallas Cowboys]] *[[Mark Murphy (safety, born 1955)|Mark Murphy]] – president, [[Green Bay Packers]] *[[Ozzie Newsome]] – general manager, [[Baltimore Ravens]] *[[Mike Tomlin]] – head coach, [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] *[[John Elway]] – general manager, [[Denver Broncos]] *[[Sean Payton]] – head coach, [[New Orleans Saints]]
